characters: ALONG THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE
AT THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE
AT THE TOP OF THE FLAG POLE
OVER THIS, A SCREAMING. A HIGH-PITCHED, CHILLING, SCREAM
AT THE BACK OF THE HOUSE
IN THE SHADE OF THE TRAILER
AT THE PLACE IN THE ROAD
AT THE EDGE OF THE ARROYO

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something is rising from the Black Hills. A sphere of lig too red to be the sun. A sphere of contained fire, undula in crimson and ochre, and rising slowly, majestically, to the pulse. To the DRUM. It is the sun. But it is a Paha S sunrise. A Black Hills sunrise. And it is spectacular. The DRUM, pounds deeper, bigger, as the sun gets higher.  Stronger. Igniting a vast landscape of gentle slopes and  foothills; throwing shadows on the plains that look like, the Indians say, an old man dancing. The grass is golden. And high. The wind moves through it, snakes through it.  Slowly. BEGIN CREDITS. Voices; a TRADITIONAL INDIAN SONG (Lakota), summoning Wak Tanka - The Great Mystery. And now, rising up over one of the small land waves, a he comes into view. Shoulders. A man, running in ghostly SLO MOTION, his long black hair trailing in the wind. The IND MAN wears only buckskin pants and a bone choker around hi neck. Legs and arms churning, the man runs with antelope grace, backlit by the sunrise, bounding toward us. Running... hi heart pounding. SONG RISING... DRUM POUNDING... FIVE MORE VOICES in high-pitched tremolo join the song. And then the runner soars, like an eagle from a bluff,  airborne, flying over a small dip, arms outstretched, and would be a wondrous thing if there were not a fine, crims mist all around him and if slow motion was not suddenly  overtaken by LIVE SPEED, revealing the brutal force of gu which has slammed the Indian into the air, throwing him.  Slamming him hard into the grass. And it is over as quick and violently as a deer shot dead. LAKOTA SONG ends abruptly.

dialogues.speaker: THE GREAT PLAINS
dialogues.text: the sun burns like lava at the horizon. DRUM beats like a heart. And Somewhere off in a distant cottonwood, an OWL. Then Silence. Deep, disturbing stillness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROCK N'ROLL shatters the silence. Cars -- a multicolored metallic criss-cross reflecting of building made of mirrors -- races past an electronic bill that blinks in red skyhigh digital: PRUDENTIAL LIFE INSUR 7:59. 73 degrees. The D.C. Superhighway. And off behind it, in the distance Capital Hill holds imposing vigil, the massive cast iron  dome of The Capital, catching the sun. But everything is  soon smothered by a METRO BUS, hogging the far lane of th Beltway, leaning on its HORN. Good morning. And the rock n'roll is everybody's radio, everybody's tem

dialogues.speaker: CARBON MONOXIDE WAVE
dialogues.text: shimmers across the beltway hugging then releasing a soli vehicle that we stay with... move with... A black Nissan SX, hard-waxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the wheel -- an intense young man with close-cropp black hair, eyes hidden by sunglasses. Whatever he does f a living, he does in a suit (not expensive but well-fit. we might also note that any extra suit cash has gone inst into the silver-plated watch on his left wrist). Lean as rake, sallow in the cheeks, there is something insatiable about him -- a hungry energy that won't let him go. RAY LEVOI, late 20's, early 30's, pulls out of a threaten traffic jam and races on the narrow right between thirty  cars and a cement girder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The black SX has jumped off an exit and has entered the l industrial section of Washington. It pulls up near a load dock behind an old gray building and several parked cars vans. Ray steps out, smooths his jacket, locks and SETS H CAR ALARM. Another young man -- chubby, clean-shaven; in a nicer sui than Ray's -- steps out from a parked Miata, and approach Ray. CARL PODJWICK balances a coffee, a U.S.A. Today and black eel-skin briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Nice tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't get too attached.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking briskly toward the loading dock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya got the paper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They mount steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're my hero, Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heroes ain't supposed to shake. I'm  shakin', man, look at me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathe, Carl. Four, nice, deep ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop at the door of a service elevator and Carl brea Expanding his chest, exhaling. Ray adjusts Carl's tie for him, his collar. He speaks quietly. Quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone stops us going in, we're with  the Bowen-Hamilton Textile Company.  We have rug samples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rug samples.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are one-dimensional, boring  peddlers of fine carpet, Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl nods. Ray hesitates, adjusts his own collar and ente the service elevator. Carl follows. Door closes. BEGIN CREDITS END.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl follows Ray into the big sparse room of unfinished  sheetrock walls. There is nothing in here but cardboard b and two people; a bearded HISPANIC MAN standing behind a  counter, writing on a clipboard. The other is a middle-ag BLACK MAN in a purple silk shirt sitting in a chair with newspaper held open. He barely looks over the top of the  Wall Street Journal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look who's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, my man, what's happenin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray walks up to the counter. Carl lingers, fidgeting. Ray sets his briefcase on the counter and click-clicks it ope The Hispanic fence man looks inside, and begins pulling o stacks of treasury checks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clean ones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Immaculate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gestures to Carl and he nervously sets his briefcase the counter, fumbles with the first latch. The second. He flips it open. The fence man casts his eyes down at a neat cache of Grad Treasury. A lot of it. Then his eyes rise to Carl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ya got there, seventy-five  thousand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred and ten. Count it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have the girl count it, we can't sit  around here countin' bonds, we got  things to do here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The fence man pushes an intercom button and yells into a  speaker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SALLLLY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl's eyes flit to Ray. Ray's eyes flit to Carl. Louis crushes his newspaper down and lifts a big Colt Pyt from his lap just as -- A section of sheetrock kicks open and THREE FEDERAL OFFIC bust out, each clutching a handgun, SHOUTING inaudibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: F.B.I.! Get your face on the fuckin'  floor! MOVE!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl startled, does an almost effeminate dip down to one  knee, but that knee is swept out from under him, slapping him flat onto plywood where he is instantly frisked down the fence man who is wielding a 9 mm handgun. But the whi collar criminal is more stunned by the fact that -- Ray is walking across the floor with his hands in his poc over to the Mr. Coffee. He pours one, and adds some milk. Turns and watches the bust while opening a packet of Swee n'Low.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slam dunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beauty. Beauty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray rests his weight against the coffee station, takes a  careful sip. Carl is yanked to his feet by the fence man he stands there, looking at Ray, baffled. Completely shoc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ, Larry, what the fu--  Larry. That's not even your name, is  it? What's your real name, you fucking  scumbag?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't have one, Carl. I have a number,  man. Just like the numbers on those  treasury checks. You stole from your  own country, Carl. Shame on you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee in hand, Ray walks briskly toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sugar Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns. Louis takes a few steps toward him, putting hi gun back in his waistband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They want ya Home. Upstairs wants to  see ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stands frozen, holding the door knob, and digesting w are apparently influential words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make sure ya spell my name right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray just stares for a moment. Then hurries out the door. Carl, being arm-gripped by two agents and photographed li a trout, gazes bewildered at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) We just spent four months together...  I thought he was my friend... what  the fuck, man? (even more incredulous) He had dinner at my mother's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAMERA FLASHES at him, an agent on either side, striking natural pose.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: The huge, imposing, mausoleum-like Hoover building, borde by artificial turf, hemmed by cherry trees in blossom. Tu out to be a nice day on Pennsylvania Avenue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8x10 BLACK AND WHITE PHOTOS dealt like cards onto a table one on top of another. 1 -- an aerial shot of some wasteland. 2 -- a closer bird's eye of the same, what looks like a N photo of Mars. 3 -- a vast expanse of the Great Plains. ROBERT F. TULLY, Number-Two-in-Command, deals a fourth ph onto the table. He is an understated, fatherly man, well- manicured in cotton pencil-striped shirt, white-tab colla and tie. The photos and maps and files a foot deep on the huge table are neatly organized.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SA Levoi, Sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seated, at the far end of the table, engrossed in the dee spread of information, SA (Special Agent) FRANK COUTURE i about to break the record for longest single ash on the e of a cigarette and the smoke forces his eyes into tight,  concentrating, slits. "COOCH" as they call him in the Bur has seen thirty years in some rough "provinces". He has  survived the Hoover era and is a legend in the Sessions e but survival has honed an edge. An edge with a touch of i cop humor. Ray enters, walks into a firm shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mister Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want a coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, no. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sits nervously across from Cooch who looks up from th photos and studies the younger man through reading glasse and cigarette smoke, and he looks at him like he doesn't  know who the hell he is or why he's sitting there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Levoi, Cooch. Raymond Levoi, Criminal  Division.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah -- right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch sticks his cigarette in his left hand, shakes with right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray this is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank Couture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The handshake is still locked. Cooch is still squinting a the younger agent. Ray obviously knows something about Ag Couture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an honor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully leans back in his chair, crosses his legs casually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, we're taking you off the street.  We need you out in South Dakota.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's enthusiasm suddenly deflates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: South Dakota... (confused) Did I do something unsatisfactory,  Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ray. You're gonna have to blame  that on your grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks completely baffled now, swinging a look from Co to Tully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interesting bloodline you have, Ray. (scanning file) French, Scots-Irish, Italian, ...and  one-eighth American Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sioux Indian, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not that sure. Yeah, I think --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- yes, Teton Sioux. Father's side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods, looks from Tully to Cooch. What's going on here

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, there's been a homicide out in  an area known as The Badlands. Indian  Reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not the first. There's been  several. And our field office in  Rapid City is getting a lot of heat...  none of the investigations have turned  up jack shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The main problem is, Ray, these people  are extremely distrustful of  outsiders, non-Indians. Relations  have not been amicable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Different culture. Hard to penetrate.  The Indians don't like white cops  poking around. And that's why we're  in a position where we have to bring  in an American Indian agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tully straightens the edges of a bureau memorandum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With an Indian representative out  there, we hope to keep hostilities  dormant; this is a COINTELPRO,  Selective Operations Unit, and it'll  be easier on Agent Couture if you  can gain the people's trust and maybe --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woh, excuse me, Sir... I see what  you're saying... I've got a little  Indian blood, that's true. But -- (laughing) I am not an... an Indian. I can't  just go in and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- your father was part Sioux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A beat. Ray lowers his eyes to the photos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't know him, Sir. He passed  away when I was six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks up at Cooch. Another uneasy beat. Cooch lights cigarette as if lighting a cigarette was a science.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, Ray. As long  as the people have proof that we  sent them one of their own, no one's  gonna ask you to weave baskets or  make it rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sits before the files and photos, looking unsure. He come to garner a promotion but has just been sent to The  Graveyard. Or in the FBI argot, Indian Country. Tully pivots his leather chair in a full circle and slaps assignment folder down in front of the young agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The very landscape from opening image. Gentle waves of la rolling out to touch the Black Hills. The sun rises up ou of the distant silhouette like a waking God. HEARTBEAT DR Hypnotic. And then a car blows by, throwing up gravel and agate and gypsum. ZOOOOM! Right by us. Gone. When a dense screen of red dust clears, an old, bent, met sign at roadside becomes visible. It reads, through punch and rusted bullet holes: "Entering Bear Creek Indian  Reservation." HEARTBEAT DRUM calls in the high-pitched, mournful voices LAKOTA SINGERS. The same haunting song.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch is at the wheel. Ray, passenger. His lap is a desk several folders, and he works through them as they drive. Both agents eat a sandwich as they travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight murders in less than a year.  All of them Indian. All of them  unsolved. Is the law a non-entity  out here or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch opens a folder that sits between them, and taking h eyes off the road for a dangerous five seconds, locates s photos, and hands them to Ray. Ray's expression tells us  they are not pretty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those are two agents who went into a  reservation a few years ago to serve  a warrant. They were executed at  close range. That one there is a  police officer killed by the Mohawks  up in Canada more recently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agents who have worked out here  say its like going into Nam.  Unfamiliar terrain, foreign language,  foreign customs... and you never  know when you might walk into a few  rounds. They hold a lot of old anger  for the white man out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray considers this as he looks out at the unfamiliar terr while on the RADIO, a D.J. speaks in LAKOTA LANGUAGE. Ray back at Cooch, studying his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you in Nam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Airborne. That's where they used to  get us agents from. Now we get 'em  from Carnegie-Melon, Ivy League.  Accountants and computer whiz-kids.  Yuppies with guns. (lights a smoke) That's scary shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray smiles, sets the AC on high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not as scary as a Hoover man with a  computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch throws a quick look Ray's way. And a smile. He  appreciates the sting of a right off a left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, hey, hey. J. Edgar would've  loved you. He'd love anybody who  joined the bureau to, what was it?  "To enforce the laws of my country  and protect her interests"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You crashed my file?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I consulted it. We're going into  Indian Country, I wanna know what  kind of individual is covering my  ass. Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray has finished his sandwich. He wipes his hands on a  kerchief while taking in the sight of chalky buttes cramm roadside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been in the bureau for thirty  years. You survived The Hoov, the  Black Panthers and Abscam. I don't  see any bullet holes. That's good  enough for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch looks at Ray, amused. He likes this guy. And then h notices a look of growing consternation on his partner's  face.

dialogues.speaker: MOVING
dialogues.text: as they drive through the first settlement, a little, bro and scattered community, littered with wrecked cars on bl and overpopulated with hungry dogs. HEARTBEAT DRUM softly under. SIX INDIAN CHILDREN with dirty but beautiful faces and lo blue black hair run alongside the car, curious. One of th YELLS SOMETHING we don't understand. PAST the trading post -- a white man's store -- where SIX OGLALA SIOUX -- four men, two women sit like wax figures, only their eyes moving to light on the freshly waxed  government car. A little house has a tipi erected beside it. And a satell dish. The house beside that one has been half chopped awa to feed the wood stove. Poverty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The federal car drives out of the community and further i vast bluffs and strange rock formations where it is swall leaving the ramshackle village in dust. A lone dog -- all its ribs showing -- chases, BARKING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are on the Moon. Or Israel. But not America. Not any  America we've ever seen. A thirty-mile eroded landscape o dunes and crevices, soft rock strata and fossils. Barren. And eerie. A LAKOTA DEATH SONG underscores the otherworld ambiance of this place as -- SHOES scuff through the gumbo and multi-colored stones. T pair of black, spit-shined, lace-ups. Three. Tripping.  Scuffing. And then a fourth pair. But they are not loafer They are Georgio Brutini's and they belong to -- Ray, as he and Cooch follow two Special Agents from the  regional office. SA MILES is about Cooch's age, balding. SHERMAN is closer to Ray's age but instead of a suit like the rest, he favors an army-green jacket. Neither is a So Dakota shit-kicker but transplanted field agents. All fou shield their eyes with dark glasses, and here in the Badl it is wise because the sun makes dunes shimmy and craters become faces. It plays mischief on the eye, making Ray an Sherman nearly trip on --

dialogues.speaker: A DEAD BODY
dialogues.text: lying face down in the rainbow sand. Dried blood and hors flies cover his blown out torso. The agents stand over hi breathless from the rugged walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who found him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indian kids. Hunting fossils.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch studies the body from where he stands. Sherman hand file over to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. I think Agent Levoi and I can  proceed from here. What are your  call signals?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PX-10 and 11. Anything we can do to  help you out, just radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Thanks, Guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agents start back through the Badlands. Ray is alread squatting a safe distance from the body, covering his nos with a kerchief while looking in the file. Cooch takes a bended knee on the other side of the body.  Flies buzz on and around the corpse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Fast Elk... Thirty seven...  single... Member of the Tribal  Council.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch makes a note then slowly circles the body. He holds hand out to Ray and the younger agent turns the file over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like Fast Elk wasn't fast enough  to outrun that load. What do you  make of the damage?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gets closer, swats at Flies with the folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six rounds. 357.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what it looks like, doesn't  it? But that's what a ten gauge,  choke-bored, shotgun will look like  when it hits your lower back from  five feet away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks up impressed. Cooch rises and walks off gingerl scanning the surroundings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody was serious about doing  this guy, that's for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch is standing ten feet away, staring at the ground. R walks over, carefully. He follows Cooch's frown down at t twisted layers of earth.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE GROUND
dialogues.text: a circle has been etched deep in the soft gumbo, and in t center of the circle, a white eagle plume sticks straight up, dancing in the wind. Cooch and Ray each lower themselves to their haunches to  study the strange sight. Cooch puts his reading glasses o stares at it. Then lights a cigarette. Ray hefts up a camera and begins CLICKING off shots. He s moving around it, taking shots at different angles. And t the sound of a DISTANT MOTOR draws both agent's attention

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: way out in the bizarre moonscape of eroded rock and earth lone figure on a motorcycle bounces and grinds, born out a silvery heat mirage. It's fifty yards off but heading  straight for us. The HEARTBEAT DRUM. REVERSE - RAY AND COOCH try to make the figure out.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE BADLANDS
dialogues.text: the archaic mud-caked Harley chugs and stalls, spits and  choices, and begins an incredible drive straight up the s side of this natural wonder. At the throttle is an imposi figure. WALTER CROW HORSE is a portly Indian in his late-thirties with a black reservation hat worn low over a face that se to have been cast from a bust of Sitting Bull. Sitting Bu with aviator shades. Denim jacket over checkered shirt. F jeans. Well broken duct-taped boots. His hair is worn lon in tight duel braids. The rusted bike bajas up and down slopes, finally stallin out, twenty feet or so from the murder site. Crow Horse s his bulk off the bike like dismounting a horse. He looks  around suspiciously then pulls a rolled-up blanket from t carrier rack.

dialogues.speaker: LEO LITTLE SKY
dialogues.text: lies in death. Crow Horse's boots move in stealthily, cre like saddle leather. He squats and looks at the corpse... then looks around wi animal alertness. He reaches into the front pocket of his jacket and pulls out some Bull Durham tobacco. He pinches some and offers it to the four directions around the body He then unrolls the blanket, begins to move the dead man. sense something and wheels to see Cooch standing behind h one hand behind his back where his gun must be, and the o hand holding up open wallet. The sun hits his badge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse hawks his eyes onto a big rock, a full second  before Ray steps out, his .45 drawn but held at ease. Crow Horse slowly raises his arms as Ray moves up to him, studying him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Taking ol' Leo somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo's been out here too long, man.  I'm taking him to ceremonial burial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a restricted area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check him out, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray frisks the Indian, finds an old leather wallet, and t a gun. A .38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice piece. You come back here to  cover your tracks, Geronimo? What's  your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It ain't Geronimo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think maybe you guys got off the  wrong exit, yeah? This is the Bear  Creek Indian Reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch walks around to the front of Crow Horse, and studie him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know where I am. I'm on federal  land, doing a federal investigation,  and if you don't wanna cooperate you  can take a ride in a federal car,  and spend the rest of the day in a  little room, answering federal  questions. It's your call. Who are  you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a full blood Oglala Sioux, born  and raised on this reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a wise-ass. Ray check his  wallet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the fuck is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- a fucking cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pause. A long, dead of South Dakota, Badlands pause. Co turns and looks at Ray who holds up the open wallet, reve a badge. Like Cooch's it shines in the sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter Crow Horse. Tribal Police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch stands staring at the Indian... then takes a few st over to Ray and grabs the wallet. He examines it. Then lo at Crow Horse and laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a fucking cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indian cop has plenty of time to get up on his own bu he kneels there, tauntingly, waiting for Ray to help him. Ray walks over and offers a hand. Crow Horse takes it, an pulls himself up, looking square into Ray's sunglasses. Cooch walks over and hands the officer his wallet, and hi .23. Crow Horse takes the items, eyeing the older agent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the wire ya was comin'. You're  the Indian official, yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, that's Ray, here. Ray, uh... (searching his  imagination) Ray... Little Weasel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray does a take but quickly recovers, meeting Crow Horse' scrutinizing gaze. Crow Horse nods to Ray, and Ray nods b in case it's the Indian thing to do. Crow Horse nods agai Ray nods again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo's gotta get to burial, Brother.  He's gotta make the journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What journey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stares at Crow Horse, uneasy. The wind sings through Badlands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo has to take the journey, Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll have to give Leo a refund.  Because he's gotta go to the M.E. In  case you don't know, Officer,  violation of the Major Crimes Act on --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- an Indian Reservation is within  the jurisdiction of the Federal Bureau  of Intimidation. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse says something in Sioux to Ray. Ray just stare

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said when can Leo be taken to  ceremony?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After we've completed our  investigation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse is staring at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a nice suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks offended. Cooch puts a hand on Crow Horse's sho and walks him toward his beat-up motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody must be doing something  somewhere in your jurisdiction,  Officer Crow Foot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't gonna cut his hands off  and send 'em to Washinton, are ya?  They done that to one of our girls  once. Leo did quillwork, he's gonna  need his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse turns and looks at Ray. Ray is quick this time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo's gonna need his hands, Cooch.  He does quillwork.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think Leo's retired from quillwork  for the moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Respect the dead, Hoss. Because when --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- did you understand me when I said  that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (walking away) -- violation of the Major Crimes Act  on an Indian Reservation is within  the jurisdiction of the Federal Bureau  of Instigation. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse appears to be getting on his bike when suddenl he moves like a cat and lays his knife to the dead man's  head. He cuts away a patch of hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His mother needs a piece of his hair.  It's for the Keeping of the Souls  Ceremony. (wrapping lock of  hair) Has to be kept for four days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch and Ray stand there, watching Crow Horse mount his  bike and push off down a nasty slope back through the  Badlands. He starts his motor. It dies. Then starts again

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keeping of the souls. Do they still  burn their dead or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats the hell outta me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Cooch look off across the Badlands, as far out of their element as they can be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: in the circle in the sand, fluttering in the wind. The gold spit-shined Le Baron eases to a crawl, passing a old wooden sign. "Leaving Bear Creak Indian Reservation." And immediately pulling in front of a squat old bar with burned out neon Miller light. DWIGHT YOAKUM croons "Youuu Got-Your Little-Ways" on the jukebox from inside. The Buffalo Butte bar has several cracked and sun-bleache buffalo skulls hanging off the edge of its flat roof and faded white letters painted across the front read: "No In Allowed." (This sign actually exists today in the res-line border t of Scenic, South Dakota). The car pulls up beside a pick- and parks. Ray and Cooch step out, careful to walk wide a a PITBULL in the bed of the truck. A WHITE LOCAL walks out of the bar and looks askance at t suits. As the two feds approach the bar, Cooch looks up a the warning sign. Ray sees it too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Ray. You're gonna have to  wait in the car. I'll bring you out  a cheeseburger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The young agent smiles, amused, starts to enter the bar b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray spins quickly, paranoid about entering. But the man  calling to them is -- An Indian himself. TRIBAL PRESIDENT OLIVER CLEAR MOON, a  small man in his late fifties who peers out at the agents through fat bifocals. He wears a straw cowboy hat, red  windbreaker and his hair is cut short, or "bobtailed" as Indians say. Clear Moon is walking away from a parked pick-up truck, t the white men, eyeing the two with deep curiosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (heavy Indian accent) You made it. Was-te.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch discreetly peeks into a folder as he walks toward t man

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be... President Clear Bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear Moon. (pointing to the sky) Moon. You must be the Sioux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is pointing his long, skinny finger at Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. That's Ray here. Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quickly) Ray Levoi, Sir. Pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear Moon beholds the young agent with hopeful eyes, a s breaking across his flaccid brown skin. He takes Ray's ha in a respectful double-clutch and grips him tightly... al desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about time they sent us one of  our own. Was-te.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps pumping Ray's hand, looking into his face with g admiration. Cooch looks on with amusement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things are no good here. It is like  war zone. We need an official who  understands what is good for the  Indian people. Who knows Indian way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear Moon has not released Ray's arm as he leads them to string of seedy motel units across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we were staying on the  reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Rooms thirteen and fourteen are  on Indian land.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you hungry? I have some nice raw  kidney in the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm set, Sir. I'm set.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's starving, Mr. Clear Moon. Get  him some raw kidney. He hasn't had  any Indian food in days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Clear Moon guides them through the front door of room 13. Ray looks over his shoulder threateningly at Cooch wh winks and pats his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lone headlight appears out of the black. HEARTBEAT DRUM But faster. Relentless. A "res" car, a dented, rusted, pe old station wagon, drives slowly toward the reservation. Then suddenly, someone steps in front of the car. A BIG M in cowboy boots and blue jeans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray lies in bed. Awake. He is hanging off the bed with a  file open on the floor and using the moon to light photos and memorandums. And then he hears LAUGHTER outside. And  GLASS BREAK. He gets out of bed quickly, snatching up his pants, putti their on, and going to the window.

dialogues.speaker: OUT WINDOW
dialogues.text: SEVERAL LOCALS out in front of the bar help a middle-aged INDIAN MAN out of the station wagon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where you goin'? Back to the res?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young local bends down behind the Indian while another  shoves him, sending him tripping over the bent man and on his back in the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ya doin'? You drunk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MORE LOCALS come out from the bar, beers and drinks and  interested in what's going on.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: at the window, observes. Cooch enters from the connecting room, puffy-eyed but quickly buttoning his shirt. He shar Ray's view.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indian man, is pushed into a stumble, and caught by  another white man as a little game of catch takes place.  Cooch, stepping into the circle, shirt half unbuttoned, h a mess, looks on. Then steps in front of a big local and  catches the Indian as he comes stumbling. He holds onto h looking at the faces that turn his way. Ray steps up besi him, looking tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's goin' on here? (a beat) I can't walk across the goddamn street  without some breed-ass fallin' all  over me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then Cooch shoves the Indian with all his might back  across the road. The locals resume their fun, and Cooch l at a local man and shares a chattering laugh that makes R do a serious take.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out now, he wants a kiss, Ray,  wants a kiss --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indian ends up stumbling back toward Ray, and Ray cat him this time. The man maintains a perfect vacant express and keeps acting as though nothing of the sort is happeni But he is dizzy, and exhausted, and Ray keeps him from  falling. Cooch looks at Ray. Their eyes meet. Ray shoves the man  forward. This time, instead of catching him, the local on the receiving end, hauls off and punches him in the face. The Indian drops. Cooch runs in, grabs the Indian under the arms and drags back to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, skin, get your ass back on  your sacred land. Get outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shoves him behind the wheel as the locals crowd around They don't see Cooch throw the wheel stick in drive, and  lean into the man's ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get outta here. Drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch slams the door, and kicks it, and the vehicle lurch forward. A beer can clanks off the rear window, and rolls clanking into the middle of the road. Ray stands there with the locals as they all watch the ca drive off across the reservation line. Cooch, belly stick out of his unbuttoned shirt, and a breathless smile on hi face, heads to the bar without breaking stride. This man done "underground" before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch and Ray sit in a booth with DENNIS VAUGHN, a strapp local man, ranch-raised, and gentlemanly. In fact, downri likeable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what type of salesmen are you  gentlemen anyway?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liquor. We heard they like their  drink on the reservation, and we  were gonna see if we couldn't unload  some surplus on the way to Nebraska.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now keep that between us, Dennis,  cuz I don't know what kinda Johnny  Law they got here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Brooks, come over here. I want  you to meet a coupla fellas from  Denver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BROOKS, a small, older man with a feed store cap and a cl cowboy shirt, comes over with a beer and a pensive look o his face. He pulls up a chair and positions himself at th end of the booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liquor salesmen. Be nice to them,  maybe they'll give you a sample of  some of that gin you like. (to Ray) He likes that Russian shit that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They ain't liquor salesmen. They're  FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch and Ray don't flinch. Dennis does. He looks between the two, cautiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brooks, what's a perceptive fellow  like you, doing in a joint like this?  Let me buy you a glass of some of  that Russian shit you like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI? What you investigatin'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A murder. On the reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again. Figures, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll never find out who did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You underestimate me, Brooks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. You underestimate these grass  niggers. They're killing each other.  That's all they do. Get drunk and  kill each other. Then cover for each  other. Who gives a damn really as  long as they stay on their  reservation. You ask me, the  government shouldn't care one  particle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how in your big cities, you  got your niggers and you got your  Puerto Ricans? Well out here we got  Indians. That's just the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only good Indian is a dead Indian,  does that old adage still hold true  out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch laughs good-naturedly. Ray smiles. But Brooks looks offended.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That set-to you saw out front, was  nothin' more than a message we were  sendin' to the sonsabitches that are  divertin' water from the river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got rights. We got a ranch just  up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray catches this. Glances a look off Cooch who works on a cold draught beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did any of you gentlemen know Leo  Fast Elk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both men shake their heads. Get quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fellas are here to investigate a  Indian crime, you should keep to  Indian land, and talk to them, not  us. But you wanna drink here and  shoot stick here, that's your right,  and we respect that. (to Dennis) Come on, Son, we're up on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fellas wanna play doubles?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch shakes his head, distracted, and the two locals lea enroute for the pool table. Ray watches them go, curious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Cooch, cross the street back to the motel. It is  black and chillingly still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Water. Worth killing for out here,  I'd think.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get the plate numbers off everyone  of these cars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I already did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch looks at Ray, impressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop in front of their rooms and Cooch pulls a small tape recorder from his waistband. A micro-cassette record that he examines in the dim door light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (locals) -- out here we got our Indians. And  that's the way it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch shuts it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time you get to the main  village, sun'll be up. I want you to  fraternize. Socialize. Penetrate.  Infiltrate. Eat some raw kidney, and  get these Indians talking. I'm gonna  Powwow with Big Chief Clear Moon and  find out more about Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands Ray the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch starts for his room but in a long, exaggerated coun step as he breaks into the HANK WILLIAMS tune that has al but driven him insane inside the joint. Ray watches him g and cracks a laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's at the wheel, looks intense as he studies the vast  expanse of slopes and rock formations and the rising sphe of flame that lights the road in strange color. He is rea a name list that he traps against the wheel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hobert Standing-Buffalo-That-Walks- Dreamer. (a dry run) Hello, I'm looking for Hobert Standing- Buffalo-That-Walks... Dreamer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray pulls up a long dirt drive and parks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray walks to the front door of a war-torn trailer that is halfway swallowed by weeds and plants. It is static out h Dead still. Ray approaches the front door. There is a hug hole in it. He knocks above the hole. After a moment, the door opens a crack. A dark, weather-b face barely shows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. I'm looking for Hobert- Buffalo-Dreaming... (cheat sheet) Hobert Standing-Buffalo-That-Walks--

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door closes. Locks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: --Dreamer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stands there for a moment then lowers himself to look through the huge hole in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tattered chair is pushed against the door, covering the hole. Ray stands up, turns on the steps. And before he ca let out a flustered sigh, he spots something across the d road. Something that makes him remove his shades, look ag Whatever it is, it doesn't make him happy, and he is hurr across the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A motorcycle, parked between the road and the badlands. W seen the ancient bike before. Ray walks past it, looking it. He pushes his shades up on the bridge of his nose and loo down into the moonscape. Walter Crow Horse is down there, on his haunches, "feel  tracking", laying his fingers inside tracks and reading t He doesn't even look up at the sound of the FBI agent's  footsteps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray Little Weasel. FBI. I like the  way ya sneaked up on me. Must be  Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind whistles and moans through the Badlands as Crow  Horse continues feel tracking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch out!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray draws back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're steppin' on sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse lowers his face to the ground and blows some  scattered dust out of a print. Lightly lays his fingers i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. (ignored) Hey, you, listen up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Leo wasn't killed here. He was  dumped here. Out of a vehicle. Bald  tread. Muffler held on with baling  wire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse checks out another track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man you want... stepped outta  the car, dragged Leo out, laid him  down. Then walked over here and made  a circle in the earth with a stick.  I can't find the stick. He stuck an  eagle plume in the circle, got back  in his car, dustin' his own prints  with a pine bough for about six feet,  but he missed a print, right here,  see. He got in his car and went Hell- bent-for-Holy-Sunday outta here. He  ditched that pine bough three miles  across the flat, in the Little Bear  River, it floated down to  Thundershield Gap. The car hit paved  road, and was outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse rises, points down the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The killin' was done where Leo's  mother lives. But he was driven here  into these Badlands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is frowning at the big Indian, trying to get a fix on this

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big sonuvabuck. Based on the depth  of that print, pressure releases...  I'd say he goes two-ten, two-fifteen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Well, maybe two-seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're trying to tell me you can  read all that from a track?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Not just a track. You gotta listen  to the trees, man. To the leaves. To  this sand, you FBI's kicked all up.  You gotta listen to the earth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right? Well, listen to this:  drag your ass. This is a restricted  area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, this is the home of the Oglala  Sioux and I want the dog-fucker who  killed Leo. Whether you get him or I  get him, I just want him. Shit's  been goin' on too long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got no jurisdiction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got no know-how. About Indian  Way. Or about Jack Shit for that  matter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you're not aware of this, Crow  Horse, but I just flew in from a  place called the Twentieth Century  where we have such things as  electrostatic tracking methods,  psycholingusitics, DNA fingerprinting;  I don't have to crawl around with  the scorpions and talk to the fucking  trees to get answers. Leo was killed  right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to the M.E., take a look  inside Leo's exit wounds and tell me  how chicken feed got in there. Trust  me, there ain't chickens in the  Badlands. His mother's place is --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- his mother never lived here. She  was from up in North Dakota.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talkin' his spiritual mother.  Maisy Blue Legs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His spiritual mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To us Indians, our spiritual relatives  are as close as family. I've got  seven mothers on this reservation.  Sisters. Brothers. You ain't one of  them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank God. Now listen to me, asshole.  I'm giving you a break. But if my  partner finds out you're here, you're  gonna be reading rat tracks in Sioux  Falls Maximum Security.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy. Easy... I'm goin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse walks back up toward the road. Ray lets him leave then crouches where Crow Horse was, be looking at tracks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Little Weasel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns, and sees Crow Horse perched on a high bank -- one Ray came down -- and he's in a tracking stance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weigh one sixty-three, yeah? Not  a beer drinker. You're one of these  tofu and pilaf characters. Pack your  gun, under your coat -- left shoulder.  But you got backup; a little .32,  .38 maybe, in a ankle holster that  gives you a right foot drag, Shoes  are too tight at the toe but, man,  they look cool. And that's what  counts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray just stands frozen, blown away. Crow Horse rises, dus off his hands, and heading to his vehicle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Indian turns. The wind moans. Ray scrutinizes him,  deliberating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse grins and waves, and ambles away. DOWN IN

dialogues.speaker: THE BADLANDS
dialogues.text: Ray stands, sweating under his suit jacket, and not sure he's amazed or pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: EXT MAISY BLUE LEGS HOUSE
dialogues.text: A trailer sits off from the river in beaten solitude. The are two junked cars and one burned black. Wind blows across deep bald tire tracks. Ray walks slowly beside them, surveying, following them to a place where t become puckers and skids next to a dilapidated outhouse.  There is a shotgun blast in the side of it. Ray studies i enters the outhouse. Exits, and walks the rutted gumbo ea to where it meets rolling hills of golden grass. He stand here, mesmerized. CHICKENS scratch around in the dirt. Like so many far-off res homesteads, this is a haunting p Made more so by a persistent SQUEAKING, a rusty, metallic squeal coming from --

dialogues.speaker: A WATER PUMP
dialogues.text: across the yard, where MAISY BLUE LEGS, a Sioux elder, wo the handle. She wears thick bifocals and keeps her hair u a bandanna. No water comes forth from the pump, and she t again and again until she breaks a sweat. And then she se the waal'cu standing out there. Urgently, she turns and starts back to her trailer with a empty coffee can. Ray starts after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs... Blue Legs? Can I ask you a  few questions --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (1/3 res speed) -- go away. Leave us alone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ma'am, Please --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She mounts the metal steps. Ray is losing her. He gets a  foot on the bottom step, and attempts something he does n want to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Blue Legs. I'm Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Halfway through the screendoor, Maisy turns and looks at young man in suit and shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Sioux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maisy lowers her bifocals, studies him. Then walks in, sl the door shut, and locks it. A towel hung as a shade fold down. Ray lingers at the bottom of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he walks around the side of the trailer, looking at t ground. In the gaping space between the trailer blocks, a the grass, there is much junk stored, and Ray kneels to l He is drawn to a pair of cowboy boots, caked with dried m He picks up a boot, looks at the sole, then touches the m His fingers break through the hardened crust and come bac moist and blue. He looks at this sniffs it. There is a te water-torture like tempo coming from the old pump where w barely drips onto a hub cap in the dirt. Ray sets the boo down. Goes to grab the other boot and -- a WESTERN DIAMOND BACK RATTLER coils out from the shade o the boot, RATTLING and HISSING from white mouth and three inch fangs, and Ray has done a backflip and roll, slappin his shoulder holster and pulling lead and BLAM! BLAAAM! h unloads two, and the reptile is so dead, there's not even enough snake left to make a truck-stop key chain. He kneels there, flushed in the face, holding his breath double-clutching his gun. The SHOTS ECHO through the Badl like the aftermath of dynamite. From inside the trailer, can hear CRYING. A low moaning. Praying softly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit. Mrs. Blue Legs! It's okay!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then his RADIO CRACKS IN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: X21, give me a 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (yelling) Black Tail District, X22. You ready  for this? Leo wasn't killed in the  Badlands. I... I found the location.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maisy Blue Legs place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got one up on ya.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got the doer. I know who he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meet me at base. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch. You're my hero.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks down at the dead snake, still rushed from it, a he hurries out of there.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE SHADE OF THE TRAILER
dialogues.text: the snake's RATTLE moves spasmodically, still kicking wit reflex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON an AMERICAN FLAG, flapping in the hot night wind But something is wrong about the image. The flag is hung  upside lit by -- A full moon that also illuminates an overgrown field that fronts a small, one-level house where the flag hangs. Thr old cars decorate the front yard. A busted screendoor cre in the wind, and somewhere off in the hills, a DOG BARKS  away his boredom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Looks Twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SA Couture and SA Levoi sit inside the car, staking out t little place far down a dirt road on the outskirts of the settlement. Cooch has the suspect's file on his knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the leaders of the Warriors  of All Red Nations. Militant  organization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hands an open file over to Ray. CLOSE ON - FILE PHOTO: a raging fire and six long-haired, fist-raising Indians, yelling at the camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The progressive Indians don't like  them because they want everybody to  go back to the old Indian ways, and  the old way Indians don't like them  because they use violence to get  attention.

dialogues.speaker: RAY SHUFFLES TO
dialogues.text: PHOTO 2 -- a big Indian in a wheel chair, holding a rifle He is shirtless under a vest and on his muscular right  shoulder there is a clearly defined tattoo of a circle wi an eagle feather through it. PHOTO 3 -- a Close Up of the tattoo. PHOTO 4 -- a propaganda flyer with the letters W.A.R.N. a the same symbol -- perfect circle, pierced by a white eag feather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: White eagle feather through the  circle. That's their symbol.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray shuffles through more of the same with great interest

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They obviously wanted it to be known  that they offed Leo. Some kind of  statement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy Looks Twice put Leo's head  through a glass door of the tribal  offices three months ago. And  threatened him several times since.  President Clear Moon and the regional  FBI feel he made good on that threat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch takes a long, tight breath then turns around in his seat, coming up with an M-16. Ray lifts one of his own. H looks out the car window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd just like five minutes alone  with the motherfucker who hung that  flag upside down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, Cowboy. No vendettas on my  ship. Now: remember what I told you  about Nam? Watch the grass, watch  the trees, watch the shit house, be  on your toes, and if we get committed,  don't hesitate to empty that sucker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Alright.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch whacks a top clip into the M-16. Ray slams a clip i his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's show time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Car doors open in skillful silence.

dialogues.speaker: LOOKS TWICE HOUSE
dialogues.text: and Ray maneuver toward the house, rifles ready. Cooch ge under the picture window, sneaks a look. Nothing. He foll Ray around the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: off in a backfield, lit by a hot fire, a small round hut  covered in patchwork quilts, canvas and buffalo hide. A  strange mist floats around it, and from inside, voices ar heard -- A DRUMMING AND CHANTING in LAKOTA. And EAGLE SOU Dozens of shrill whistles. Are there birds inside this th

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: and Cooch, kneeling in the weeds, look dumbfounded. And m than a little unnerved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) What the hell is that?

dialogues.speaker: NEAR THE INIPI LODGE
dialogues.text: An INDIAN YOUTH DOOR TENDER with shoulder length hair fal over a T-shirt, steps out of the dark and walks to the fi He prods it with a broken pitch fork. He turns to get some more wood and walks right into an M- trained chest level. Ray stares him down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy drops boot camp fast. Cooch moves up on the sweat lodge, looking quizzically at it, trying to figure out how to open it. He grabs a canva flap at the front and after a moment's hesitation and a l at Ray, he tears the flap away. A BLAST OF 200 DEGREE STEAM explodes forth and Cooch danc back, throwing up his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inside lodge) Mitakue Oyasin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRANDPA SAMUEL REACHES, a rail-thin Sioux elder, appears  through the steam like a vision. Bent in the tiny doorway he searches out the interruption. Cooch aims the M-16 at the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the FBI! Come on out of there  nice and slow. Let's move it! Hands  on your head!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa Reaches crawls out first, ignoring the "Hands on  your head" order from Cooch. His eyes move back and forth between the two agents. FIVE MORE INDIANS, from 16-45 come out, looking confused. Cooch makes the towel-wrapped men spread out in a line. T old man is speaking to the others in LAKOTA, and Ray step up to him, cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hands on your head, Sir. Come on,  come on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The archaic figure just looks through him. Starts to walk away. Ray takes his thin arm. He locks eyes with the old  man. Slowly, he obeys, raising his hands and laying them his head. From the lodge, the last man emerges. It's Crazy Horse re out of the burning sage. JIMMY LOOKS TWICE is in his mid- thirties -- big, well over two-hundred pounds. But lean. braids fall nearly to his hips. His face is handsome but the moment, twisted in a full-blood's scowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (outraged) What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James Looks Twice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. What are you doing  here? This is a religious ceremony  you're desecrating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks Twice shoots hawk-like black eyes onto Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're FBI, James. We just need to  ask you a few questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are in the middle of a sweat lodge  ceremony. Do you drag people out of  your churches when they're in the  middle of prayer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's take a walk, Jimmy. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch takes a careful step behind Jimmy and cuffs him. Lo Twice speaks to the others in LAKOTA, and they disband,  heading to a shade arbor where their clothes hang. As Cooch starts marching Looks Twice toward the house, Ra keeps an eye on the departing. One of them stops halfway the fence and turns. Grandpa Reaches looks at Ray with ey that have seen one hundred and one hard years in Indian  Country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead. You can all go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he follows Cooch and the cuffed Jimmy to the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just wanna take a look around  your place, Jimmy. We're not here to  bust your balls.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BACK OF THE HOUSE
dialogues.text: Cooch leads the half-naked suspect to the backdoor. Cooch show: a warrant, tries the door but it is locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your good friend Leo Fast Elk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think I killed him? Cuz he was  an apple? Well, let me tell you  something about Leo, Man --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- don't "man" me, Jimmy. Where's  the key?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy doesn't answer. He glares with hatred into Cooch's  eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, use the federal master key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray steps up, gets ready to throw a frontkick at the door

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Don't do that. Don't deface the  property, man. The key's in there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With his hands cuffed, he can only jerk his head toward a big hole in the wall down near the foundation. Cooch quic drops to a knee and checks out the hole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside... in the coffee can.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch reaches in, probes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no coffee can in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something horrifying happens so fast, Cooch has no time t react. Whatever has taken his arm has done so with such force, h body jolts like he's touched raw voltage. The South Dakot BADGER rips through his leather jacket -- we get a glimps of its striped face and yellowed teeth -- through his shi Through flesh, and deeper, GROWLING insanely while COOCH  HOLLERS in shock tries to pull free and -- Jimmy Looks Twice spins from the porch with a skillfully  executed back kick, knocking Ray off the step and to the  ground. The Indian bolts like a deer into the darkness. Ray rolls in the grass, throwing his M-16 up. He hesitate But only for a moment before FIRING and decimating the co gutter, a junked car, several trees. But no sign of Jimmy Cooch falls back in the grass badly mauled. His arm has b ripped open down to the bone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus... Jesus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray starts toward Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray takes off, crashing through weeds, into a stream, wad through mud. He throws his flashlight left and right. He  crosses the river, shines the light in a field of wild sa Nothing. He runs like a sprinter, looking everywhere. But he enters an --

dialogues.speaker: OPEN FIELD
dialogues.text: all he finds is Jimmy's towel. He picks it up and looks a the area, breathing heavily. And then suddenly, something leaps up out of the grass. R swings his M-16 up, ready to blast. But it is a DEER, tak off into a mystical blue night. THE DRUM. Beating fast. H TURTLESHELL RATTLE. EAGLE BONE WHISTLES.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE YARD
dialogues.text: Cooch traps his bleeding arm between his knees to stanch blood. He speaks quietly but firm into his radio, trying stay in control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio) Assault on federal officers. Suspect  has left the area. One officer down.  Issue a Fugitive Alert immediately.  Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Has the officer been shot, X-22?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, the officer's been bitten by a  fucking badger, okay? Get a Fugitive  Alert fucking now! Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mind-blowing Aurora. Living clouds. The incredible mesa PULLING BACK slowly to the dirt road where a line of fede aerials high, enter Indian Country. HEARTBEAT DRUM. But a fast heartbeat. A relentless pulse  throughout --

dialogues.speaker: AN FBI SATURATION SEARCH
dialogues.text: FOUR AGENTS surround a little tar-paper shack, rifles up ready. Two go in, and flush out an OLD WOMAN, an OLD MAN, and some TEN CHILDREN. DOGS. A SMALL TRAILER that has thirty junked cars in its yard a serves as a reservation parts store is crawling with FEDE MARSHALS; car doors are being opened, trunks. TRACKING DO run through the cars. WARPATH DRUMS... -- A BELL UH 1-B "HUEY" HELICOPTER chutters low over the  grasslands, over the Badlands, flattening wheat. It swing down over the main settlement. CHILDREN gather in the str to look up at it but then run when -- -- SIX FEDERAL CARS come down the main road. They pass by -- THE FRONT PORCH OF THE TRADING POST where Ray stands,  talking to the elders. A few of the same from earlier but several new ones. He is sweat-drenched, and has shed his jacket and tie. He showing them photos of Jimmy but getting no response. And then, for a little iodine on top of that, a MOTORCYCLE EN spitting and choking and coughing comes around the corner Walter Crow Horse, manning the handlebars. He pulls up to Ray and just looks at him. DRUMS FADE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an easy man to track, Ray. Ya  walk like a penguin with a hard-on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right? What are the trees  saying today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're sayin' that nobody's gonna  talk to you cuz they don't give away  one of their own. But they did say  there's somebody way across the Little  Walking River who wants to talk to  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray soaks sweat off his forehead as he eyes the Indian on this one. He sees himself in the polaroid shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sent me to find ya. He says he's  got information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray quickly leaves the porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silent. The unnerving silence of the Great Plains filled  only by FLYS, big horseflies, buzzing around drying sage  that hangs from the rafters of a shade arbor. A GOAT stan under it, just gazing across -- the vast spread of grass and dry land where an ancient  Airstream trailer sits lop-sided. Sheets are hung as curt Six old cars -- two from the early 50'a -- sit stripped t the hubs on blocks in the overgrown grass. The air is dry and heavy and the only sound is -- FLYS. Ray swats at them as he steps over a truck seat tha lies in the grass, stuffing and springs hanging out. Crow Horse walk. a few steps ahead, toward the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with reverence) Grandpa Samuel Reaches. Heavy duty  medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Medicine. As in medicine man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse nods slowly, looking at Ray in a very serious  manner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why does he wanna see me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good question. Hardly sees anybody  anymore. Hasn't left this place in  twenty years. Did you bring some  tobacco?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse stops walking, making Ray do the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you go see an elder, you always  bring some tobacco as a gift.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray reaches into his shirt pocket and fishes out a pack o Marlboro. Crow Horse glances at it, and shrug-nods. They  continue on toward the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa Samuel Reaches sits in a taped and tuckered easy  chair, his alert black eyes moving from side to side. We  recognize him from the sweat lodge ceremony at Looks Twic although today he wears a straw cowboy hat giving him a m youthful look despite a face like a map of the Badlands. He wears a vest over a western shirt, baggy work slacks, cowboy boots. His brown wrinkled hands run over the top of the Marlboro pack as if he's reading braille. Crow Horse sits across from him on a stool. Ray leans on of the plain green walls, looking uncomfortable. A three  foot adhesive fly strip hangs from the ceiling, thick wit dead ones. There is a black and white TV with Sesame Stre wailing, honking and guffawing through static. Grandpa fixes his eyes on Ray for only split seconds at a time but one gets the feeling he's doing an incredibly de reading of the young man. Slowly, he sits up -- focusing  intensely on Ray. He begins to speak. A hoarse, strained, string of LAKOTA, spoken like it used to be, gesturing toward Ray. When he  finishes, he sits back in his chair. Ray looks intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to know if you ever watch  the Cookie Monster. He says the Cookie  Monster is not to be trusted -- a  trickster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks puzzled. Crow Horse laughs bull-wild as Grandpa takes up a fly swatter and takes out a big horsefly. The man begins speaking Indian again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says there's something wrong with  Big Bird -- he's crazy, (stops laughing) He says you stopped the Inipi ceremony  last night...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse turns a questioning look at Ray. Ray doesn't  flinch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But he is not unhappy with you because  he knows you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He knows me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he saw you in a vision some  time ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse stops translating suddenly even though the old man continues speaking. Crow Horse looks concerned, and A A QUESTION IN LAKOTA. We don't know what he's asking but tone is absolute amazement. This question triggers an exchange between he and Grandpa the old one getting angry. Grandpa wins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess he had this vision some time  ago, in the Moon of the Popping Trees --  uh, back in the winter. He says you  come from Wasi'cu city in the East  but that your people... way back...  are of the Minniconjou Sioux. But  you yourself don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray's brow is drawn tense as he stares at the old Indian, absorbing the translation. Grandpa speaks more fervently  now, incorporating Indian sign. Each time Grandpa does th hard Sioux HAND SLAP, Ray blinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says he knew you'd be coming to  Bear Creek. He was told. It is the  will of Tunkasilia -- the grandfather  that you come here. He says let's  smoke the caanunpa the sacred pipe,  symbol of truth. So that there will  be no lies between us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man has taken a long wooden stem and a red stone  bowl from a beaded pipe bag. He joins the two together th begins offering a pinch of tobacco to the Four Directions While this goes on, Ray fidgets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he smoke in that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sacred herbs. Tobacco. Don't worry,  we don't smoke no Mexican agriculture  in The Pipe. That's a white man's  myth. This is a sacrament.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man is offering the pipe to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mltaku Oyasin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks at Grandpa. The old man offers the pipe again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't smoke with him, it means  you're hiding something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray takes the pipe, looks at it... then passes it to Crow Horse. The big Indian takes it from Ray, giving him a lon eye, then offering the pipe to The Directions before smok Crow Horse puffs hard, eyes closed, then slowly releases  some smoke upward. Ray watches it climb and fade. The old man then takes up an old turtle shell rattle. He speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says Wakan. Sacred. Five hundred  year old turtleshell rattle, passed  down from the Grandfathers. Heavy  duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shakes the rattle very slightly, moving it in front of Ray. He speaks just above a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says, it is good. The Spirits are  here. The Spirits want to know what  you're doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell him I'm trying to find the man  who murdered Leo Fast Elk. Ask him  if he knows where he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse asks the old man in Lakota. No answer. The pip is back to grandpa, and he offers it to the Directions, t the Earth then upward before smoking himself. He begins t speak again. Passionately. In long glottal Sioux sentences, adding sig fingers crossing, brushing an arm, a slap here and there, He is working himself into an excited state, and Ray keep looking at Crow Horse, very interested in the old man's  answer. Finally Grandpa's breath comes up short and wheezing, he  ends his oratory with a solid hand slap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said he doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He just did the Gettysburg Address  in Sioux. What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse ignores him. Grandpa speaks again. More hand  language. The old man is staring at Ray while whispering to Crow Ho He strokes his badger claw necklace. Crow Horse looks at Ray and seems hesitant to translate t new piece of information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... Grandpa likes to trade; no one  stops by here without gettin' stuck  in the old Indian barter. He, uh...  he likes your shades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa smiles toothlessly. Ray who has his driving glass in hand, lifts them to say "these?" but Grandpa sees it a an accepted deal, and swiftly removes his necklace. He ho it out. Ray slowly, hesitantly surrenders his sunglasses, and tak the necklace. Crow Horse bursts into laughter and so does Grandpa, enjoying a good trade. He draws a hand through t air in a sort of horizontal karate chop, meaning done dea Ray looks confused. Out of his element. And out of his sh Another fly gets snagged on sticky tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse is hurrying toward his bike, Ray with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
