dialogues.text: What was he saying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why should I tell you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he was talking to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse keeps walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he know something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse stops walking and eyes Ray, deliberating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man saw an owl. Over there  in the dry wash. Last week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He saw an owl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A silent moment. Ray tries to figure out what he's missin here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owl is a messenger. When one  shows itself to a Sioux... it means  someone's gonna die. The owl told  him about Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stares vacantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The owl told him about Leo. That's  incredible. I guess we just broke  the back of this investigation, didn't  we? Evidence doesn't get any harder  than that -- not for my money. Is  there anyway we can seduce this owl  into Federal Court?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He also said "listen to the water."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to the water. Listen to the  owl. He also said, don't trust the  fucking Cookie Monster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go back to your DNA finger-printin'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse KICK STARTS his bike and burns off down the dr Ray feels the presence of the old man, standing behind th busted screen door. Just watching.

dialogues.speaker: OVER THIS, A SCREAMING. A HIGH-PITCHED, CHILLING, SCREAM
dialogues.text: that takes us straight into --

dialogues.speaker: SLACK TAIL POWWOW GROUNDS
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON A TERRIFYING FACE -- painted in blazing red and  yellow, black around the eyes. A ridge of feathers high a the hairline, and a mouth open, tongue trilling -- SCREAM

dialogues.speaker: A WACIPI
dialogues.text: is going down. A Powow. Held in the center of a huge arbo This DANCER, a traditional Kit Fox dancer, is dressed in  authentic costume and is dancing with TEN OTHERS dressed various traditional garb and paints. Under the arbor, TWO HUNDRED INDIANS in modern clothing s on blankets or in lawn chairs, watching the dancing. A gr of SINGERS sit around a big drum, beating on it, and wail the song that keeps the dancers hopping. SIXTY CARS (res beaters) are parked off around the arbor, less interested kids sitting on them, smoking cigarettes. few actually have MTV hair-cuts. Drifting through the cars and people are Special Agents  Couture, Miles, Sherman and Levoi. They stroll through,  incongruously, checking out faces. Vehicles. Ray slows his step and takes in --

dialogues.speaker: THE POWWOW CIRCLE
dialogues.text: as the dance ends. WEAK APPLAUSE. The POWWOW CALLER, a bi Sioux with a crew-cut and cowboy shirt, speaks through a  scratchy P.A. system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was-te Yelo! Let's have five more  veterans. Five more veterans. Hoka  Hey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An OLD-INDIAN MAN sitting in a lawn chair, removes his co hat and reaches down toward a blanket. He brings up his V hat, adorned with medals and puts it on. Slowly, he rises and shuffles out to the center pole along with -- FOUR OTHER VETERANS who have exchanged cowboy hats for  veteran's caps. There is even a traditional dancer in the wearing a veteran cap. As a mournful WAR SONG is banged o by the singers, a flag is unrolled by the veterans. An  American Flag. Unrolled, and set on the mast. And togethe all five Indian men, hoist --

dialogues.speaker: THE AMERICAN FLAG
dialogues.text: high. Slowly it climbs. Proudly. It blows in the hot Sout Dakota wind.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE ARBOR
dialogues.text: Ray stands, watching this. And then the SONG ENDS. A loud angry voice breaks across the P.A.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CROW'S NEST, (CALLER'S BOOTH)
dialogues.text: ANDERSON CHASING HAWK, a young Indian in ribbon shirt and long hair has taken possession of the microphone. SIX W.A MEMBERS stand behind him. He speaks loud, firm, with the  sharp gestures of an old way Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is that that you honor there,  uncles? After all the Wasi'cu country  has done to you, after all he still  does to you, you honor that flag?!  That flag has been desecrated by the  United States, because they have not  honored what that flag represents!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The veterans just stand under the flag, solemn, looking a Chasing Hawk. The flag undulates soundlessly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To them, we are the Bank of America.  Whenever they get into a little  difficulty, they go to The Bank,  withdraw a little land, withdraw a  little oil --

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE ARBOR
dialogues.text: the four FBI agents stand, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Here we go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's this guy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anderson Chasing Hawk. Second in  command behind Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE CROW'S NEST
dialogues.text: Chasing Hawk hands the mic over to another Warrior. MAGGI EAGLE BEAR would be the most beautiful woman Ray has even seen if she was not the meanest-looking. Her thick black  hair falls over a denim jacket down below her horse-hair  belt. Her faded jeans are stuffed into worn cowboy boots. And she is full of fire. She begins speaking in LAKOTA.  Fluently. And with hand sign, like the old man.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE ARBOR
dialogues.text: the agents stand. Cooch is writing into a small notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Magedelana Eagle Bear. Eagle's claws  and a bear's balls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She keeps an AR-15 assault rifle in  her truck. And she'll use it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Ray watches her, someone approaches in a less hostile  manner. It is President Clear Moon, looking very upset. H holds the hand of a LITTLE GIRL, dressed in traditional  dancing garb. He approaches Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Clear Moon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our police are afraid of them. Please  get them out of here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear Moon gestures for the little girl to run off. He le in close to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to kill me next. That's  what I hear. These new Indians are  destroying everything. Our people  are a quiet people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They can lead us to Jimmy. Just let  them go. We're tightening the net on  him. We know he's on the reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear Moon is looking past Ray at the Warriors. They are  approaching the agents, and Clear Moon looks at Ray with  great concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he slowly retreats to his lawn chair under the arbor. Chasing Hawk, Maggie and the other Warriors strut up to t agents. All but one who is bound to a wheelchair. We've s RICHARD YELLOW BIRD, the big Cheyenne who wears a Red Pow baseball cap, an earring, and thick bifocals -- in one of the file photos. His arms are plastered with tattoos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Jimmy? We thought he'd be  dancing today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The warriors make a show of not acknowledging the FBI  presence. They have walked over here just to walk by them That is there statement. But Yellow Bird stops cranking t wheels of his chair and stop: long enough to look up at R

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you the Washington Redskin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even the agents crack grins at this bit of Indian wit. Al but Ray who just stands there, arms folded across his che considering the crippled activist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say hello to Richard Yellow Bird,  Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Bird sits there, staring up at him through thick  glasses But then Maggie Eagle Bear takes the handles of Y Bird's wheel chair. She looks at Ray with eyes that are c cherry black, eyes that look right through him. He return the glare. And then she pushes Yellowbird forward and lea the feds alone. Ray turns to Cooch who is lighting a cigarette, and  concentrating on the movements of this group as they wand under the arbor, visiting people. LAKOTA SINGERS start up

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, get to Jimmy's place and keep  it tight. I'm gonna get a tail on  his Warriors.

dialogues.speaker: IN THE POWWOW CENTER
dialogues.text: the under ten year-old "fancy dance" -- TWENTY-FIVE INDIA CHILDREN, whirling and stomping and dancing.

dialogues.speaker: JIMMY LOOKS TWICE HOUSE
dialogues.text: The battered old house sits under a full moon. The upside down flag moves slightly in the cross winds.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE ROAD
dialogues.text: several junked cars. Among them a black, rusted out VW va with a smashed windshield. A PACK OF RES DOGS sniff at it tires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dim light, a boot. A black cowboy boot. Up on the  dash. Bluejeans. T-shirt. Second hand leather. And a blac cowboy hat. Ray is staking out Jimmy's house. Across the passenger seat and console is an M-16 rifle. O his belt, a .357 Red Hawk. He yawns. From outside, he hea a sound. POV: down below the van, a small, patchy RES DOG with a  missing leg is looking up at him with his tongue long and salivating. RAY breaks off a piece of sandwich and drops it down to h just as -- HEADLIGHTS catch his face. He slides down low, watching an old pick-up truck creak onto the dirt road,  leading to Jimmy's. POV: the truck parks. Someone jumps out, gracefully. Indi Long braid. Quick steps. Front door. Inside. RAY lifts his radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: X22. Read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go ahead, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a pick-up truck. No plates.  Subject -- Indian -- entering  suspect's house. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Ray. I'm coming in. If he starts  to leave the area, move in. And hold  him. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sets his radio down, unclips the leather guard on his handgun. Picks up the Big Mac.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The front door creaks open, and the subject dashes back o In the dark we cannot latch onto features. Suddenly the junker van comes alive, guns onto the dirt r racing toward the running Indian who gets the door of the truck open but freezes in the van's highbeams as -- Ray leaps out, M-16 in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FBI, freeze, Motherfucker -- drop  it, drop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray maneuvers in Quantico fashion, keeping the rifle on t Indian's back. The Indian drops what he's holding. And tu around. It's not a he. We've seen her before. At the Poww Maggie Eagle Bear. Her hair is pulled back tight, braided Ray moves in toward her, surprised at first, but still  cautious

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Turn around, put your hands on the  roof of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She does what he tells her. As Ray moves in on her, he no an INDIAN CHILD sitting in the passenger seat, looking ou into the highbeams, frightened. Ray toes Maggie's legs out wider, frisks her one-handed,  pats down her boots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the Indian FBI.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. Turn around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie turns around, looks Ray in the eye. He looks self- conscious in the cowboy hat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people are glad they sent you.  They usually send in guys who come  at ya with highbeams, screamin' "drop  it, Motherfucker", stick a gun in  your face, frisk ya down. Even if ya  got a child with ya. No, it's good  to have ya. It's gonna be was-te  times on the res.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is looking down at what she dropped. A bundle lying i the grass. He bends down, starts to untie it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was gonna warn ya about messin'  with somebody's medicine bundle but  I forgot you know all about that  stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN THE BUNDLE -- an eagle skull, tobacco strings, sage, s grass, and several white eagle feathers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Jimmy's?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not gonna catch him. He can  shape-shift into different animals.  Bear. Elk. Porcupine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that like an hereditary thing,  Magdelana, or can one take classes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy didn't kill Leo. Why do you  wanna do this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He tried to kill him twice before.  That's a good place to start don't  ya think? Leo was on the other side,  wasn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Leo was an apple, that's right.  Red on the outside, white on the  inside. And Jimmy hated him. Kicked  his ass a coupla times. But he didn't  kill him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're the FBI. That's your job,  isn't it? Ya know how many of our  Warrior brothers got killed out here?  I never saw any investigating then.  Why now? What's going down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Fugitive Alert for a murder suspect.  Before somebody else gets a shotgun  blast in the spine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try the Fort Laramie Treaty. All  over again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray doesn't have a clue as to what this radical bullshit about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look. You and I can stand here in a  culture clash til the sun comes up,  talking about what's right and what's  wrong. You're from the reservation.  It's a different world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from Minneapolis. Fifth Street.  I did four years at Dartmouth before  I ever set foot on this res. So I  know about the other world, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If this information doesn't throw Ray, the use of his fir name does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna keep that medicine  bundle or are you gonna respect its  power?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is holding the medicine bundle. He deliberates, then  hands it over. She takes it with careful hands, casting a somewhat surprised look up at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you see Jimmy, tell him the  sooner he turns himself back into a  human being and gives himself in...  the sooner we back off this  reservation. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie gets in the truck, starts it up. She looks out at  him, studying him. Trying to figure him out. HEADLIGHTS a coming fast from down the main road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa Reaches says you come from  heavy Indian blood. I used to think  Grandpa was gettin' senile. Now I  know he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Move it, Magdelana.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie drives forward, turning down another little wagon  road, and bumping into the black night only moments befor Cooch's Le Baron pulls in. SA Miles and Sherman's vehicle pull in behind it. The reg feds fall in behind Cooch, everyone, packing rifles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns, nodding. An FBI van pulls in from the other  direction and FOUR AGENTS empty out, wearing FBI windbrea and heavily-armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do we got, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just Eagle Bear. I questioned  and released her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd she say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She talks a lot of shit. We're not  doing our job. Jimmy's innocent.  "What's the FBI really doing here."  Some shit about the Fort Laramie  Treaty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch nods. The agents form a tight unit out below the up down flag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She took something from the house.  What she called a medicine bundle.  Most likely Jimmy's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave it back to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it is Jimmy's, she's taking it to  him. We'll have a runner. But I  borrowed a little mojo...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray reaches inside his pant leg, down around his boot and carefully removes a white eagle feather. He gingerly tuck it in a plastic bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way to go, Raymond. Miles, take that  to lab. Sherman, I want you to go  back to base and produce some written  material. Something that indicates  that our girl Maggie is leaking  information to us. And make sure  that material finds its way into the  hands of the Warrior Movement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherman and Miles, take off. Cooch, an impressive master COINTELPRO, now turns to the van squad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gentlemen missed that medicine  basket. Go back through the house,  and make sure you missed nothing  else. And lay some wire, too. Let's  do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van squad moves toward the house, leaving Cooch and R alone in the highbeams that light the yard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good goddamn work, Ray. Let  the salmon run. Let 'em run Upriver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why we setting Eagle Bear up as an  informant?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her own people start to suspect her,  it creates discord from within. The  Warriors don't know who to trust,  they start infighting, and Jimmy  loses his support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods, impressed. Cooch bends down near the road, touches the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her oil pan is shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch. What's the Fort Laramie Treaty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, I don't know. You tell me.  You're the Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch wipes the oil on a handkerchief as he rises, smilin playfully at Ray. He starts back toward his car. Some sor of bird is COOING in the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a tail on her, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks up at the upside down flag. Then watches Cooch  walking way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch. (a quiet, tired laugh) Where the fuck did they send us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long way from home. You be careful  out there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch, standing there with his glasses on and his right a bandaged, looks tired, too. He gets in his car. In the yard, Ray starts for the van, the res dog, trying follow. He chases it away. And then as he gets closer to van, he looks up to investigate the COOING SOUND.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE TOP OF THE FLAG POLE
dialogues.text: there is a shadow. What looks to be a large bird. It just hovers. In the shadows.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BELOW
dialogues.text: Ray looks up at the pole, watching. Then walking on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mind-blowing sunrise of airbrush red. Clusters of lodge-p pine. The spectacular mesa. PAINT HORSES graze in a field few out in the center of the road.

dialogues.speaker: AT GRANDPA REACHES TRAILER
dialogues.text: the old man comes down the front steps in a frail walk,  carrying a paper plate. He steps down into the sage clust that grow just off his trailer, and offers the plate up t the sky. He then stoops, and scrapes a half-eaten English muffin,  some potato chips and half a banana onto the Earth in a n pile. He straightens his back the best he can, looks up again, prays softly.

dialogues.speaker: THE BADLANDS
dialogues.text: possess an otherworldly beauty at this magic hour, a maze shadows and rainbows. In the distance we cannot mistake t frame of Walter Crow Horse. He's out there, long hair blo against the white bluffs. Stalking. Tracking.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE VILLAGE ROAD
dialogues.text: a puppy chases a hen in a klutzy, innocent manner then bu into the tire of a parked car. Taking a shot at doghood, hikes his leg, squirts a hubcap belonging to -- Cooch's Le Baron. Cooch leans on the hood, drinking a cof from a foam-plastic cup, and supervising SIX G-MEN who ha a map spread out over the hood and are discussing it.

dialogues.speaker: MAGGIE EAGLE BEAR'S HOUSE
dialogues.text: is way out in a remote corner of the res, a little home,  trailer and tipi right on the river. The river is rushing hard this morning, catching the light of the sun. Maggie' truck is parked in front. Out at the river, Maggie, her hair long and unbrushed, an wearing an extra large T-shirt and nothing else is haulin water in buckets from the river. THREE INDIAN CHILDREN are with her, helping her. Near the house, an OLD WOMAN in bifocal glasses, feeds some chicke and a cat that gathers with the chickens and eats feed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray, still in his field clothes sits, training binoculars the distant house. He opens a carton of milk, drinks some Then hears a whimpering. In the passenger seat sits the t legged res dog. Ray has taken him with him. He drinks som milk, then opens the carton up fully and sticks it out so the dog can lap it up. Ray laughs in disbelief, shaking h head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For all I know, you're Jimmy. And  you're just waiting for a shot at my  jugular. Drink, Jimmy. Milk is good  for you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dog is lapping the milk, desperately. And then a ROAR A motorcycle. IN THE SIDE MIRROR: Crow Horse, racing up on the left of van. Ray pulls his hat down low, and sits back. The motor passes on the left, slowing enough so that Crow Horse can flip Ray the middle finger. Then he races on, far down th road. Ray sits there, shaking his head. He'll let it go. Bullsh He starts the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse guns in, sliding in dirt up to the run-down, l budget shooting range -- six plastic milk jugs on sticks, jammed in the mud. A moment later, the van hammers in. Parks. Ray gets out.  He's removed his hat so as not to invite any crap from Cr Horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't be mad. That was just an old  traditional gesture that means hello,  how are you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. Forgive my cultural ignorance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray executes a hard, slapping, "up your ass" gesture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a nice day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse bursts into laughter in his raspy, staccato la He walks off a few steps, picks up a spent shell and pitc it. His laughter simmers and he gets serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jimmy didn't do it, Ray. I checked  it out. You can stop taggin' my  sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's your sister?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spiritual sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gotchya. We just nailed a genetic  match between the eagle feather left  at the murder site and one in Jimmy's  medicine bundle. It came from a white  eagle. Same bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse fingers an eagle feather that hangs from his h band.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did this one. Wambli is a rare  and sacred creature. When someone  finds a dead one, the feathers get  around the res. We share everything.  A lot of power in the eagle feathers.  But you think that's bullshit too,  don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ala Crow Horse) -- Leo Fast Elk was sitting in the  outhouse at Maisy Blue Legs when a  car pulled into the yard. He came  out, approached the vehicle then saw  that the man behind the wheel was  Jimmy. He tried to get back into the  trailer, but the car came highballing  at him. He started running for the  open grass. With the car moving,  Jimmy hung his shotgun out the window,  took aim -- missed once, hitting the  shitter -- fired again, and severed  Leo's spine. Leo fell, rolled, and  came to a stop in the grass. And  some chicken feed. Stale chicken  feed with four days mold. (a beat) Electromagnetic printing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse stares, a little surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was-te. 'Cept for one thing. Jimmy  Looks Twice was nowhere near there.  Ya see, when Jimmy was twelve years  old, his mother and father was killed  in a car wreck right down there near  Elk Mountain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't see the connection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The connection is, it did a head  number on him. He's petrified of  cars. Won't drive. I've known him  all my life, and he's never gotten  behind the wheel of a vehicle. He  rides passenger and he rides horses,  and that's it. The man that shot Leo  down was behind the wheel of a moving  car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray absorbs this with great interest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want solid? That one, single,  print he left in the Badlands -- the  one the FBI missed and then stepped  all over -- it belongs to a man who  walks heels first. Like a white man.  Jimmy has a serious Ind'n walk --  ball of the foot first. The man who  murdered Leo walked like a Wasi'cu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray lets a pent-up sigh escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying a white guy did it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse chews this over, unable to hide a nagging  frustration. He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Leo was dumped out there in the  Badlands, he was dropped on his back.  Our man made an effort to turn him  over, onto his face. It's an old  Ind'n belief that if a dead man is  turned face down, his spirit won't  leave. And in the killer's case, it  won't come back and jump all over  his shit. That's an Ind'n thing a  white man wouldn't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them stand there, thinking this over. Ray take out his notebook and starts writing. Crow Horse walks awa turns to face the propped up targets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And that's the way it is. Write it  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To punctuate, Crow Horse slaps leather, draws his .38, an begins blasting at the milk bottles. He hits the bank. A  tree. One of the posts. But not a single target. When he is done, he looks over his gun, disappointed. Sta reloading. Ray starts laughing, looking at the missed tar

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You laugh all you want, Breed. Sunset  tonight, I get my man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks at Crow Horse, sees that he's serious, and foll him toward his motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, Crow Horse. I'm listening.  I'm listening to the trees, to the  stones. Who is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse turns toward Ray, and creates a long dramatic  pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damned if I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he hauls his bulk onto his motorbike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the Old One. He did a Yuwipi  ceremony last night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse winks at Ray as he slams the kickstart. To no  avail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man? He's gonna tell you who  killed Leo?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go catch Jimmy, Ray. Really. He's  gettin' away. Go ahead, go get him.  I'm late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey. Hey, those are my sunglasses  you're wearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa traded with me. (flips the bird) Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Crow Horse nails his kick start. The BIKE ROARS alive and the Indian works the throttle hard, leaving gravel an black exhaust. Ray stands there, drifting between logic a instinct. He looks at his watch, then starts at a slow,  thoughtful shuffle toward his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dust-buzzard broncs and bounces down Grandpa's drivew coming to a stop near the wrecked cars. Crow Horse dismou and unhooks a carton of smokes from the back. A moment later, the junker van pulls in, bouncing and sha Crow Horse stares at the approaching vehicle, his eyes hi behind Ray's former shades. He cracks a slow smile becaus Ray is stepping quickly from the van, and carrying two pa of Marlboros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa sits in his chair, his black eyes moving smoothly from side to side. Smoke enshrouds his ancient face, givi the sense of another time and place. He speaks LAKOTA. Crow Horse, sitting on a stool across from him, holds The Pipe. He passes it to Ray who sits in a busted lawn chair next to him. The room is dark as the sun sets out the win in red and purple. Ray looks at the pipe. Grandpa will no speak until Ray smokes. And so he does, drawing on the st awkwardly. HEARTBEAT DRUM as Grandpa speaks Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says, back behind Red Deer Table,  where the Elk-People-used-to-live...  there are strange creatures from  another world who eat stones... and  who will kill anyone who crosses  into this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks at Crow Horse, searching for a hint of lightnes But there is only great reverence as he watches Ray blow  smoke upward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says, in the Yuwipi ceremony last  night, he saw you... going back into  the land beyond Red Deer Table. I  was with you. But that was all the  Spirits let him see so he doesn't  know if you were killed or not. But  he thinks you probably were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray smirks as he passes the pipe to Grandpa. Crow Horse l nervous. Grandpa offers the pipe to the directions and th disengages the bowl from the stem. He speaks again. Crow  Horse translates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to the land where the Elk-People- used-to-live and you will find the  answers you came here looking for.  But you must go as two. That is the  vision. I have spoken. And this is  so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa leans closer to Crow Horse and whispers some Lako

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He wants to trade. (a beat) He likes your watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks at Crow Horse, nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't do that, (explaining) It's a Rolex.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Grandpa is already holding out something to offer. It a cigarette. Grandpa offers it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, this is -- (loud to Grandpa) -- this is very, very expensive.  It's -- (to Crow Horse) Tell him this is an expensive watch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse tells the Old Man. Grandpa speaks Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says, you need to go on Indian  time. He says your watch is ruining  your life anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray buries his hands in his jacket pocket. No way. Crow H signs to Grandpa "no." Grandpa gets up, crosses between t two young men, up to the TV set. He turns it on.

dialogues.speaker: WHEEL OF FORTUNE
dialogues.text: explodes in PINGS AND PONGS and a WOMAN'S SHRILL SCREAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse and Ray walk down the steps. WHEEL OF FORTUNE heard from within.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red Deer Table, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell me: heavy duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy, heavy duty. Taku Wakan. Wanagi  Spirits. It's one of those few places  we'd never go to as kids. Still don't.  Some of the old people say Crazy  Horse is buried back there. We have  to go Ray. Together. Like his vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They step into the yard and Ray stops, turning to Crow Ho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter. When I fill out my 302, do I  say that evil spirits are killing  everybody on the reservation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- no. No offense to the old man. I  appreciate you trying to help. But I  put my ass on the line coming out  here, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you expect to hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not Native American myths and legends.  I'm with the FBI, Walter, remember?  Not National Geographic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you call myths, we call our  history.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not real.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's real to you? Wall Street?  Capital Hill? Now they are myths.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't be dicking around here. That's  all I'm saying. I don't carry  crystals, I don't wanna come back in  another life. I just wanna do my  job, and do it right, and get the  fuck outta here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't no Indian. You're a Sal  Mineo Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse drives "Indian" home with a hard finger in Ray chest. Ray knocks his hand away, explosively. Crow Horse ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knock it off!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man is standing at the top of the steps. Ray and  Crow Horse are YELLING OVER EACH OTHER, and hands are up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will ya knock it off? You're actin'  like a couple of old women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stands there, one hand up in defense, another poised throw a punch. Bewildered, he stares at the old Indian ho onto the porch railing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For cryin' out loud. Knock it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He speaks English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only when he's really pissed off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come inside. Watch TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Grandpa goes back in, screendoor slapping shut behind him. Ray is just staring, his jaw dropped. Crow Horse sta laughing. Harder than he has yet, and Ray starts walking  toward his car in fuck-this steps. He gets into the car, closes the door and looks out the o window at Crow Horse. The Indian moves first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't accuse nothin' of not bein'  real, Little Weasel. Cuz the only  thing around here that ain't real is  you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray lifts his arm off the door, and springs his middle fi up at Crow Horse. He holds it there for a long moment jus looking at the big Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care of yourself, Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Likewise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray checks the time on his watch then guns away. Crow Hor stands there, watching him go. Eventually he shuffles bac toward the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Room 14 has been transformed into a major COINTELPRO base four computer terminals are set up, card tables spread wi photos, boxes of files stacked on the bed, and SIX AGENTS manning the computers, thumbing through files.

dialogues.speaker: THE CONNECTING ROOM, (RAY'S ROOM)
dialogues.text: A meeting takes place around a table of paperwork and cof cups, and a .45 laid atop a file. Cooch, SA Miles, SA She TWO OTHER REGIONAL AGENTS and Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've gotten word that Jimmy has  been trying to hook up with Maggie  Eagle Bear... but some of the Warriors  have been sending word to Jimmy that  she may be an FBI operative. So he  doesn't know where to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch taps some ashes into an empty coffee cup. They sizz in cold residue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bingo. It's working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's out of room. All the reservation  exits have been watchdogged. We got  him. I give it twelve hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well we better use those twelve hours  to apprehend the right man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agents all look at Ray. A pin can be heard falling to the cheap carpet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The right man? Talk to me, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoever dusted Leo, dusted him from  the driver's seat of a moving car  then drove those eight miles to the  Badlands. Jimmy Looks Twice has never  been behind the wheel of a car. It's  a known fact out here that he's  petrified of driving. His parents  were killed in a car wreck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch nods, lights another smoke, intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not very solid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was also a print found in the  Badlands that indicated diagetic  locomotion. Heels first. Jimmy's  walking pattern doesn't match. He  has a distinct Indian walk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indian walk? You been smoking hooch  in the peace pipe, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: LAUGHTER. Except for Cooch who just stares at Ray, digest what he has said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't smoke hooch in The Pipe,  Miles. They smoke something called  kinickinick, it's like a tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherman looks at Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're right about X21 being a  Washington Redskin, that's for sure.  What else, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You boys want a soda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, a Coke. You buying?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Ray's buying. Sherman? Coke?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... no. No, Cooch, I'm working on  a coffee here. Indian walk?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch nods to Ray and Ray follows, gathering up some pape He looks determined as a terrier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Cooch throw long, slim shadows on their way to an archaic Coke machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Genetic ditto on evidence found at  the site with evidence you found in  his belongings. An incontrovertible  motive. And definite footprints on  Jimmy Looks Twice at Maisy Blue Legs  house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When did we get that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Today. And now you -- there's a dog  in the van --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- I know. I fed it, and I can't get  rid of --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weren't sent here to go off on  your own detail, Ray. You were sent  here to assist in a Selective  Operations Unit. These regional agents  are inept -- that's why they were  sent out here to The Graveyard, to  Indian Country. I need you behind  me, Ray. Not pulling against me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not trying to pull against you,  Cooch. I've just been having  nightmares about the way Leo was  killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your first homicide, that's gonna  happen, Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanna make sure no one else  gets done in that way because we  were in bed with the wrong doer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. I never get into bed with  somebody unless I know for sure.  Just the way I was raised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray studies him with a smile building. Cooch shrugs, sips some soda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Alright...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lightly) Yeah, alright, alright -- fuck you --  give a yuppie a badge and he wants  to take over the world. Go get a  tail on Eagle Bear, and stay with  her. Cuz Jimmy's gonna show. And I  want you to make the collar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods, starting for the van.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns. Cooch looks at him for a time. It is a warm loo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll sleep around a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And get rid of the dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gets in and pulls the dog out. The dog sits at roadsi tilting its head at him, confused. And he pulls out. It r after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The van sits parked down the road from Maggie's dimly-lit home. Ray sits behind the wheel, watching the house. LOCU make a steady and unnerving sound. It is black. Black und big sky. Ray lets his head sag out the open window and he takes in the vastness. POV: stars. Millions of stars. And an incredible full moo It hangs huge over distant fields, a perfect sphere. The half of the moon is yellow, the bottom half a lava red.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: stares at it, lost in thought. From Maggie's house, he he someone SINGING. Singing a traditional SUNDANCE SONG whil they haul water from the creek. A WOMAN'S VOICE, trilling out the beautiful but haunting "hey-o-hey-o-hey-o-hey-ohh Ray just sits, listening. And then something draws his  attention to his rearview mirror. The res dog, lying in the back seat is GROWLING. Lip curl back, growling low. Ray looks at him, looks out the window. Blackness. Nothin but the sound of locusts. And a slight crosswind in the w fields. The dog stops growling. And Ray fixes his gaze on the house again, lifting a pair of binoculars and -- BOOOOOOM! The rear windshield is SHATTERED by an explosio Ray throws himself low across the passenger seat -- BOOOO The driver's side window and part of the door explodes.

dialogues.speaker: RES ROAD NEAR EAGLE BEAR'S
dialogues.text: The federal van is HAMMERED BY GUNFIRE. All the windows,  shattered, the metal doors splayed. Someone is going for kill,

dialogues.speaker: THE PASSENGER DOOR
dialogues.text: is thrown open just as its window implodes, and Ray slide out belly first, gripping his M-16 and crawling like a do soldier into tall wheat at roadside as the car, the road, the wheat, the dirt, the night are slammed by gunfire. The res dog overtakes Ray and vanishes in the wheat. Ray  vanishes, too. It is quiet for a moment, then Ray, pops u ten feet away, and UNLOADS THE M-16, in a left to right,  clean sweep before dropping again. He lies there, listeni The LOCUST HAVE GONE QUIET. His breath is heavy. His hear got to be pounding through the dirt he lays in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering) Motherfucker.

dialogues.speaker: THE ROAD
dialogues.text: the decimated van, aerial still high. The distant lights Maggie's house. And the giant Moon, hovering over it all. HEARTBEAT DRUM into --

dialogues.speaker: SAME ROAD
dialogues.text: TWENTY FEDS comb the dirt road, the wheat fields, picking shells with gloved hands, scanning the vast distance. IN THE FRONT YARD of Maggie's, FOUR INDIAN CHILDREN stand with the Old Woman, watching.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch, flushed in the face, mans the wheel. He wears only T-shirt which indicates, a desperate rush to the scene. H eyes scan the surrounding homes and fields. In the passenger seat, Ray sits, drinking a coffee. He lo haggard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bastards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I could think of was... not here.  I don't wanna eat it on an Indian  Reservation, three thousand miles  from home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's out there. He's out there playing  Sitting Bull with us. I want the  motherfucker so bad I'm getting a  bleeding ulcer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns around in his seat, looking off across dry land

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It may have been Maggie's way of  saying "get off my ass."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's that subtle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eagle's claws and a bear's balls  that's what her profile says.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, she's running now, too. These  fucking people like to run, don't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Cooch. Woh. Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He does. Ray is turned around in his seat, staring off in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron whines backward, and off the road, into some grass Ray steps out, keeping his gaze fixed. Cooch bails  from the driver's side, joins him. HEARTBEAT DRUM. RAY'S POV: Four-hundred feet across a flat area of sandst and grass clusters, something shimmers in the undulations the harsh morning sun. Something of pea green and rusty  metal... glass catches sunlight and makes prisms. A car. old res car, sitting in a long, chasm in barely a foot of green water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Cooch go through the car, around the car, with gl hands and grease pencils and plastic bags, sweating in th hot sun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tread matches. It's the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excited, Ray walks off, scanning the area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But this doesn't make any sense,  Ray. If it's just been sitting in  this dry wash for seven days... why  the hell didn't we find it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray picks up a handful of stones, sifts them in his hands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because this isn't a dry wash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch watches him slosh shoes first through a rut where t water shimmers a foot deep or less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the Little Walking River.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns, shucking up mud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it was full of water when I drove  by here three days ago. Full. I  mean... a river.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Little Walking River. You're  right. This is part of it. So whoever  sunk this car didn't compensate for  drought. Goddamn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray doesn't hear Cooch. He stares past the SAC at the lon wide chasm, wet in some places, arid in others, and what hears must be an echo in his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to the water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch is listening to a TRANSMISSION across his radio and walks off a few feet, exchanging information with the  REGIONALS. Ray stands, ankle deep in stagnant water, his face sweat- soaked, his eyes transfixed on heat undulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A flat-bed tow truck drives past the motel with the kille car on it. Behind the truck is a fed car which stops at t motel, and the Le Baron which also pulls in. Miles and Sh get out from the first car, Ray and Cooch bail from the L Baron. With RADIOS TRANSMITTING, the agents walk, dusty and tire into room 14. Ray hesitates, snagged by the sight of -- A motorcycle parked in front of the Buffalo Butte Bar. Pa with pick-up trucks and station wagons. It's the mud-cake old Barley. Parked right under the NO INDIANS sign. He puzzles over this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dark. Even during the day. Cigarette smoke. Sawdust. On t archaic juke box, RANDY TRAVIS sings "Old 8x10" while beh the bar, the BAR OWNER, an old man with long white hair a beard, busies himself with leather work. SEVERAL WHITE LO sit on the old water drum bar stools. Heads lift, turn when Ray enters in his "fraternizing" cl jeans and boots, leather jacket. He scuffs up thick sawdu as he heads to the furthest booth back where -- Crow Horse sits, alone over a bourbon and a beer. Ray  approaches carefully, upset by the sight. He slides into booth and point blanks the Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Agent Little Weasel, Federal Bura of  your Imagination.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. You're hammered. What  are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right about the old man. His  power's long dried up. He's supposed  to be a medicine man but he won't go  see the people. He says we changed,  and we don't listen. Well, he don't  go out and talk no more. I haven't  had a drink in three years but I  just turned my sobriety chip into  that man behind the bar, and this  Hoss is gettin' watered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cut the shit. You shouldn't be in  here, Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuz I'm a skin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuz you're a cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tell me. You tell me who went to  the B.I.A. -- Bureau of Indian  Annihilation and said I was messin'  with your case, man. I don't give a  goddamn about your case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I don't give a goddamn about  whether you wear a badge or not,  Crow Horse, but I didn't cut you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse shimmers his black eyes onto Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still after Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They found prints at Blue Legs' place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Jimmy's prints are there. But  they cross over Benjamin Black Star's  prints. And he wasn't there until  six o'clock the mornin' after to get  eggs from the chickens. So Jimmy  wasn't there til the next day. Follow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray just looks vacantly at Crow Horse. Crow Horse resents the vacancy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, man... you better bust Jimmy  and get out before somebody shoots  up more than your car next time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray glares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next time I'll be ready. You get the  word to who ever it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, Hoss. I don't talk to FBI's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray doesn't blink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you was sent here cuz you're  a good cop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I was sent here cuz I'm Indian.  And a good cop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse leans toward Ray and speaks more quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever think that maybe you was  sent here cuz the FBI's need one  good reason to take out the entire  Warrior Movement. And what better  reason than one of their men, gettin'  blown away on the res. A low-rent,  expendable public servant sent in to  take a bullet for his country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is fuming. He can't believe what he's hearing, what's being insinuated, but he's giving it thought and it's get him angry. He smashes a hand down on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of your shit --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of the two of ya timber  niggers spewin' off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Standing over the booth is a long, tall RANCHER'S SON. Ra with red curly hair tucked under a BLACK HILLS CLASSIC ca and arms built by tractor work. And behind him, TWO OLDER RANCHERS fall in. And ANOTHER YOUNG MAN, grinning with  amusement. Ray and Crow Horse look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, we don't speak United States.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well I do. Get the Jesus up,  and get the Jesus out or I'm gonna  go out to my truck and come back  with my hardware.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woh, hold on there, Jack, you're --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- don't "jack" me, Squanto. I'll  bury your lazy ass right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray realizes now that they think he's Indian, too. Crow H sees this revelation and complicates it by suddenly speak LAKOTA to Ray. The rancher grabs Ray by the cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm talkin' to --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray decks him. Backhands him in the solar plexus then, la a burner of a Quantico roundhouse to his ear, knocking hi across the bar, over a mop and bucket and into sawdust. The others start to fall at him but someone has jumped in holding them back, and sticking himself in the way. It is Brooks. The old timer Ray met his first night here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! No, you butt holes! He ain't  skin! He AIN'T SKIN!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah he's In'dn. Miniconjou Sioux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rancher's son who is coming back with a broken beer  bottle, slows his step and shifts his eyes from Brooks to the young fed There is a lot of heavy breathing. But no  talking just yet. The young rancher eyes Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ain't Indian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray just stands tense, staring at him. And it's strange.  Because he hasn't really looked like he has any Indian bl up to this moment. But dressed the way he is, and his eye glaring, face drawing tense, he might pass for a breed  although that's probably the Italian. But Ray doesn't ans the question. Crow Horse starts laughing. Drunkenly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's so damn funny?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it's just that the cavalry  used to always threaten the Lakota.  The cavalry ain't around anymore.  The Lakota still are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got no trouble tellin' where you  come from, Fat Red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse rises and walks unsteadily across the floor,  leaving the bar. Brooks is whispering to the others,  apparently about who Ray is. The bar man comes up to Ray, holding a tray, on which sits a shot and a beer. Ray look at it for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. On the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray knocks the tray out of his hand, spilling beer and wh all over the bar man and the locals around him. And he walks out, leaving the locals confused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks strung-out as he drives. If it's not the confli at the Butte, it's the dangerous seed Crow Horse planted, and it is playing with his mind. He is on his RADIO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No plates. No registration. Serial  numbers removed. And all prints washed  off by the river. That's great. This  is turning out to be a walk in the  park, do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (woman agent) Come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But before he hangs the radio. IT CUTS BACK IN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. X22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I read, Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Remember that upside down flag back  at Jimmy's house? Somebody took it  down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They took it down, set fire to it,  and threw it on the doorstep of room  13 at the Buffalo Butte Motel. Your  room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray seethes quietly as he drives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We traced the number of the truck  that dumped it, and it belongs to  one Maggie Sanders, also known as  Maggie Eagle Bear. She's been all  over the res, riling up the  traditionals, telling them not to  break, and to keep Jimmy in hiding.  She's a problem now. And she's yours.  Get her off the reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray keeps driving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie's old pick-up is parked near an arch gate of the t cemetery where a tall monument is fenced off from other g There are tobacco offerings and other medicines hanging o the fence and on the monument. It is a quiet place. Still. Maggie stands before the unkempt monument in her denim ja her hair blowing across her face in the wind. She PRAYS I LAKOTA. Behind her TEN CHILDREN from the Bear Creek School stand, heads bowed respectfully. Two of them sit on the lap of  Richard Yellow Bird who looks on from his wheelchair, pra quietly with Maggie. When Maggie completes her prayer, sh ties some tobacco to the monument then turns and faces th children. One of them, a LITTLE GIRL -- heavy-set -- rais a hand that we might note is deformed. As many of the chi we have seen on the res, are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they all right under here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two-hundred and sixty-seven men,  women, old people. And little ones  like you. Many killed running along  that road you see there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where were they runnin' to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A place called The Stronghold. (a beat) They died for a dream. But you live.  You are their great-great  grandchildren and you live. We have  to honor their dream. Of protecting  the Mother Earth. And being proud of  being Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother told me that they call us  Indians cuz Columbus was lookin' for  India when he discovered our country.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie smiles at the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, let me tell you something,  Henry: just be glad he wasn't looking  for Turkey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CHILDREN LAUGH. All but one boy, who isn't paying  attention. He is staring up at a hill, off in the distanc MAGGIE'S POV: on the hill, a figure stands, hands in his  pockets, hair blowing in the wind. Ray.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: keeping her eyes on the Wasi'cu, but addressing Yellow Bi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Richard. Sing the Honoring Song with  them. I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE HILL
dialogues.text: Ray stands, watching Maggie walking into the wind, toward him. Behind her an HONORING SONG, sung by ten children ha the still air. He doesn't budge as she mounts the gentle bluff and joins him there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're praying at the grave. Do you  wanna join us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long silence. The voices carry in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Maggie. But you're gonna have to  join me for a ride. I'm taking you  to Rapid City.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie looks at him. They lock eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So much power. I see it in your eyes.  This... hunger for power. Or for  what you think is power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As if exhausted by the thought, Maggie sits down on the b looking out at the children who are still singing the son As she speaks, she begins digging her fingers in the eart Ray stands over her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You burned an American flag today.  And left it for me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- You desecrated it, it had to be  burned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I desecrated it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You forced an innocent man to run  like an animal. You've tried to poison  my people's hearts against me with  your manipulation, with letters I  never wrote... you've been watching  me eat, work, raise my family...  wash myself in the river. And now  you're here, arresting me at a sacred  place. (a beat) In your eyes, that's power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie lifts herself onto her knees and looks down into t small hole she's dug. She picks up a little pine cone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I plant this tree for you. And I  take all this stuff that you've laid  on me and my people, and I put it in  this hole with this pine cone. (she covers it) And I bury it. Cuz ya know what it  is, Ray? Bullshit. And shit is  fertilizer. (she stands) And The Mother will turn your lies  into something that lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie rises, dusting off her hands. She looks him in the soul.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what power is, in the Indian  way. (holds her hands out  to be cuffed) Take me to Rapid, Ray. I'm the enemy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray just stares at her, struggling with what he's feeling what he's hearing. What he's supposed to be feeling. Sile hangs between the two of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I told you... that I think Jimmy's  innocent... but I'm in over my head...  would you believe me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie looks at him, considering. Then toward the long da silhouette of a mountain range across the plains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See those Black Hills out there,  Ray? When the people lost the land  in 1868, the government took  everything but those hills. They  allowed us to keep those Black Hills,  to live there. Signed a treaty. Until  they found gold. Then they told us  we had to leave because of National  interest. They broke that treaty.  Anyone who fought or spoke out against  it, wound up dead or in jail. And  the people wound up here. On a  reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While she looks off at Paha Sapa, Ray stares at her profi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While up there, in the Black Hills...  they carved the faces of four  presidents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at Ray with an ironic smile, and she catches hi transfixed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your relatives must've taught you  something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: NO. (after thought) My father never told anybody he had  Indian blood. But he still used a  few Indian words around the house.  He called me Washee. Said it meant...  good boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie starts giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wa-shee is like... a dumpling. Like  tallow we put in stew. I think he  was calling you chubby boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is laughing as she looks back at the children who no longer singing. Ray reaches inside his jacket and take out five polaroids. He shuffles them as he ponders. He ha one to Maggie who has caught herself opening up too much the Wasi'cu.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever see that car before?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie looks at the first photo and says nothing. She han it back quickly. Ray won't take it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's it belong to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie ignores him. Ray studies her reaction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me, Maggie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie is looking away. She picks a long blade of grass a smoothes it in her hands. Ray looks at her a moment longer then rises, dusting off jeans, and standing there. He thinks for a long moment,  pinches the bridge of his nose, then looks out at the Bla Hills, pensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't see you today, Maggie. (a beat) Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie watches him go. Looks away. Then watches him again

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye... Wa-shee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stops. She stands on the bluff, her hair riding the w and her eyes searing. And then her lips do something that might qualify as half a smile. A sense of humor rising up through anger. Survival humor. Ray looks at her for a long moment. And then he walks on, leaving her there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sits behind the wheel, going through files on his lap photographs of Indians. And thinking hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyone who fought or spoke out against  it... wound up dead or in jail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks out the window toward the monument.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to himself, flustered) That was 1868, Maggie...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhausted, Ray lays his head back on the seat, and lets a long, constricted breath free. THUNDER ROLLS like the slo deep roar of some giant bear up in the hills. He opens hi eyes, looks out the window. POV: rain is coming down, and Maggie is getting the child into the back of her truck. She helps them get a tarp ove their heads. Then as Yellow Bird pulls himself into the c of the truck, she hefts the wheelchair and two boys load in. She gets in, starts up, and rolls off down the sloping ro

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray steps out of the car into the rain and closes the doo He stares at the burial grounds. Then slowly, he starts t them as if magnetically drawn. HEARTBEAT DRUM. A shroud of mist lays over the cemetery, growing thicker the rain falls harder. DRUM BEATS DEEPER. Ray is walking  toward the memorial, getting drenched. Then he hears some strange. HOOFBEATS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: coming down the dirt road, toward him, a HORSEMAN drives mount at a fast trot. The rider is only a vague image in mist, his face hidden. As he rides closer, we can make ou shotgun in his hand. And he throws it up, takes aim.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: paralyzed for a moment. And then going for his gun. But i not there. He's left it in the car. He breaks into a run. But there's a shorter distance now between the horseman a the car and Ray has no choice but to turn and flee. His boots slap wet pavement, and his breath draws heavy a desperate as he bounds off the road and races down a gras slope, looking over his shoulder, panicking. His legs and arms churning, his face contorted. And then  someone passes him out, running just as hard. AN INDIAN W in 1890 Winter rags, clutching a BABY to her breast and  CRYING. SCREAMING. Ray looks at her, incredulous as he ru But he keeps running. The rider is right behind him. He FIRES. The GUNSHOT CRAC the sky like thunder. BOOOOM!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray jumps awake. Cooch is POUNDING on the window. And the three-legged dog inside is BARKING. Ray quickly rolls the window down, letting in THUNDER. Cooch starts to say something then takes note of Ray's pe face. Sweat runs down his temples, beads at his nose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I... I fell asleep. I can't  believe it. I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never turn your radio off! I thought  I was gonna find you scalped! Damn  it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Cooch. I lost Eagle Bear --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- never mind Eagle Bear. We've got  Jimmy nailed. Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cooch runs to his car. Ray fires the car's big engine and takes off behind Cooch who is driving a fed Chevy. CR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain pelts Grandpa's little Airstream trailer, wind s at sheet plastic in the windows. An ancient sewing wheel  CREAKS RUSTY in the wind. Three clean, late-model fed cars pull down the muddy driv as two SWAT vehicles pull in from another road. The Le Ba pulls in, and Ray bails out with the others. When he sees where he is, he looks distraught. Agents are running behind junked cars, positioning themse around the trailer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The holy man is sitting in his chair, smacking Flies with swatter. Tonight he wears a black reservation hat and sta vacantly at the TV where RONALD MACDONALD swings a giant  baseball bat, and falls on his face, bouncing back up. An then BOOM! The door is open and Cooch leads Miles, Sherman and Ray  inside. Cooch has a gun on the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANDS ON YOUR HEAD!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old man slowly removes his hat and hangs it on a knee Carefully he places his wrinkled hands on his thinning wh hair. His eyes seek out Ray who stands in the doorway, M- in hand, looking concerned. He stares at Ray. Cooch storms into a back bedroom, Miles moves to a window Sherman stands over the old man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he, Sam? Where's Jimmy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa looks at Sherman, ignores him, looks back at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a medicine man, Ray. The  "spiritual leader" of the Warriors.  That right, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With RADIO TRANSMISSIONS crackling through the house, Coo comes back down the hall, and heads to the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trailer's clean, let's go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray starts to follow but he sees Sherman pick something u from near Grandpa. The 500 year-old turtleshell rattle.  Grandpa's eyes widen slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You been the one making it rain like  that, out there, Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, put that down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you make Jimmy outrun an M-16,  Sam?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherman drops the turtleshell rattle on the linoleum floo Then drives his heel into it, CRUSHING the fragile  turtleshell. Ray grabs him and slams him into the tin wall. Miles gets between them, grabbing Sherman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EASY, MEN! HEY! --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HE'S ON THE ROOF! HE'S ON THE FUCKING  ROOF! COME ON GUYS, COME ON, GUYS!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're out the door, leaving the old man to sit looking  down at the shattered rattle. He closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a blizzard of rain, Jimmy Looks Twice in a cowboy shir jeans and boots, leaps off the top of the Airstream, clut his medicine bundle. FLOODLIGHTS HIT him from all directi BULLHORNS screaming at him. He tries to turn a corner and runs right into a fed. Ray, having run out the back door has slammed right into him. has his rifle on him, and they stare each other down for split second before he is converged on. Guns at his back, his head. He is swept off his feet, face down, and frisked. He look up at Ray, desperately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brother, the old man told me about  you. Listen to me: what was Leo trying  to tell me? He wanted to meet me at  Maisy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another fed, pushes his face into the mud, cuffs him behi his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save your speeches for prison, Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With two FIVE MAN SWAT TEAMS swarming the area, and six a pushing Jimmy toward a car, Cooch stands there in the pou rain, looking relieved. Ray stands near him, looking abho

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn. That's one hard running Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray watches Jimmy as he is shoved into the back of Miles Sherman's car and driven away. He is twisting around in h seat to look at Ray. Desperately. The SWAT teams disband, return to their vehicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, Ray. I aged five years.  But it's over. At least I'm gonna  look like I'm ready for the advisory  desk. Let's go get a beer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch heads to his car and Ray starts shuffling toward hi as if he is dared by it all. He is looking at the trailer and there on the rickety porch is Grandpa. He comes down steps slowly, holding his hat on against the wind. He wat the cars pulling out. Ray walks over to him, looking sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... I'm not who you think I am. (a long beat) I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And after a moment of locking gazes, he starts for his ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out back that way... is a placed  called Wounded Knee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was one years old there when our  people were shot down. My mother hid  me in the snow in a blanket. One of  those killed was a Holy Man called  Wakiyan Cante -- Thunder Heart. They  killed him while he was running for  The Stronghold. It is his blood --  the same blood that spilled on the  grass and snow at Wounded Knee --  that runs through your heart like a  buffalo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray frowns, disturbed by this story. The old man is speaking with conviction. With power.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thunder Heart has come. Sent here to  a troubled place to help his people.  That's what I am told. Maybe you're  right and I am mistaken. Your mind  is young, mine is old. If so, so be  it. Ho Hecetu Yelo. I'll speak no  more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stands, almost paralyzed, digesting this. He turns an looks into the old man's sharp eyes. Grandpa has closed h eyes, and as he is pulverized by the rain, he turns his f toward it and from way down in his belly, he begins to SI IN LAKOTA. And it is too much. Too weird. He wheels and  hurries to the car. Gets in, and beats a fast path out of the old man's lonesome patch of land. BLUE HEAT LIGHTNING knifes the sky. THUNDER ROLLS, and ru into POOL BALLS --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The agents have taken over both sides of the streets, gat in front of the bar and the motel, putting firearms into  cases, removing flak jackets. POOL BALLS knock from inside the bar while outside, A DAK takes a piss near a truck while his GIRLFRIEND stands at back, yelling at him. CHARLIE DANIELS sings country on th juke Ray heads to room 13, starts unlocking the door. Coo comes up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buffalo burgers and cold beer,  Raymond. Don't worry about the sign  out front... you don't have to be  Indian anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch throws a mock punch at Ray and he mock blocks, tire He musters a smile. But he isn't all there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a fever. You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods. Cooch lets a few agents walk past, LAUGHING. He speaks quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen: when we get back tomorrow,  you're gonna find Tully laying a  promotion on you. S.A.C. He wants to  prove that his yuppie agents are  making good. He's offering you New  York. Tell him you want Atlanta.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuz I want New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray tries to break a smile again. Cooch cups his arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch. They sent us out here because  the place was being neglected. Now,  all of a sudden, there's two five  man SWAT teams out there tonight.  Bell Huey choppers flying all over  the place. Federal occupation to  catch one guy. Why, Cooch? What's  going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch stares at Ray. The younger agent looks like he inde has a fever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: National security, Ray. Get some  sleep. Tomorrow, we fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch hurries across the rain-swept street. Ray steps ins and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray closes the door, and stands there. He seems to be hav trouble breathing. He looks down at his boots. There is  something on the floor. Something that has been slipped u the door earlier. He just stares down at it. Then slowly  stoops. CLOSE ON: the polaroid of the res car he gave to Maggie  earlier. She has returned it. He turns it over. Written across the whi backing of the photo, in dark black marker is the name -- YELLOW BIRD. Ray stares at this for a moment then hurries over to boxe of files on the bed. He rummages like a nervous thief and comes up with a folder. He flips through it, casting off  files and 302's and profiles and finally stopping on -- The 8x10 BLACK AND WHITE of Richard Yellow Bird seen earl Sitting in his wheelchair, Red Power cap on, tattoos marr big arms. And under it a DOUBLE MUG SHOT stamped LEAVENWO PRISON. Under that ANOTHER PRISON MUG SHOT stamped SIOUX  FALLS PRISON. And under that a -- THIRD MUG SHOT stamped "PAROLED." Ray, his eyes fixed on this one, takes a few steps and si on the end of the bed. He then stuffs the file back in a  box, and takes off toward the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron throws up loose rock and red dust, driving t a place where the sun begins a slow drop behind the Black Hills. HORSES run out of the road. HEARTBEAT DRUM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tarpaper shack. Outhouse. Clothesline on which jerked m hangs. No cars. A lonely, unnerving place. Le Baron pulls in. Ray gets out, adjusting the gun at the back of his  waistband.
