He starts for the shack. Ray raps a fist on th splintered plywood door. Knocks again. He checks out a bo up window. The door finally opens. Just a crack. Tiny bla eyes peer out into the fading light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for Richard Yellow Bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sticks his open badge, gold eagle wings, near the cra The door closes. Then unlatches and opens. Yellow Bird si there in his wheelchair, tiny tobacco bundles in his lap. He's been tying them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Washington Redskin. Thought you'd  be gone by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He pivots his chair to allow Ray room to enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Bird, in a T-shirt that reveals twenty different i tattoos, rolls himself across the warped floorboards to a cheese crate where his eye glasses sit. He puts the thick bifocals on and focuses resentfully on Ray in the ochre  flicker of the dirty room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What ya want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must be a bitch getting around in  that wheelchair. How long you been  in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I got a iron pipe put across  my knees, man. Fight with three  wasi'cus, ya know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Sioux Falls Pen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, that was Leavenworth. This -- (shows a scar) was Sioux Falls. What ya want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leavenworth a tough joint?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray walks across the room, his eyes on a covert mission.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever try solitary confinement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Can't say that I have, Richard.  Richard do you know why I'm here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Washington sent ya. I know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Washington sent me, Richard.  They sent me here because this whole  thing has been fucked. Do you know  what I mean when I say this whole  thing has been fucked, Richard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Bird stares at Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An arrangement was made between you...  and us. Do you remember that  arrangement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Bird looks at Ray, strangely, shaking his head. Ra starts to look like maybe the game's not working. Like ma this doesn't add up. But --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here, ain't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray lets a tense breath out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for long, Richard. You got early  parole under the stipulation that  you would help us in a situation,  and you didn't deliver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the fuck you talkin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sits in a busted chair, reaches down to his ankle hol and pulls out a .38. He holds it, resting it on the arm o the chair. He strains to look out through the boarded win Yellow Bird fidgets in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up out of the chair, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with you people? Why do ya  have to fuck with my head all the  time? I came through, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up out of the chair, and walk  toward the backdoor, Richard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not moving) I get thrown in solitary until I  don't know my own fuckin' name, and  then you people tell me I can beat  nine years if I help you. I helped  you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Bird stands. He takes a step forward. Limping. He' got leg problems but he can walk. Heels first. And bowed. But he can walk. He is shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They said I'd never see FBI again,  and I'm livin' with you fuckers. I  don't feed ya information on the  Warriors, it's back to the pen. I  don't do this, back to the pen. Your  word against my word. Against a con  Indian's word. I really got a chance,  man, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sent me here, Richard because  they said you didn't hold up your  end of the arrangement, and I have  to transport you back to Leavenworth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (crying) What the fuck, man? What do you people  want? I did what you wasi'cu's told  me to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo Fast Elk... is alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Bird wheels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way. No fuckin' way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How the hell do you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I blew his back out with a buffalo  gun, that's how I know! Now you're  gonna say I didn't, so you can throw  me back in solitary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is trying hard not to reveal his horror at this  confession, at this understanding of the machinery. He si there with his gun, blinking away sweat that beads at his brow. Yellow Bird is weeping in a highpitched voice that  doesn't match his great bulk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men who came to see you at  Leavenworth. The one's who made the  arrangement... who were they? Maybe  I can talk to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miles. Three other suits. That's all  I know 'em as -- suits. Were you  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You turned Leo over on his face. But  the coyotes must've turned him back  over, man, cuz his spirit is out.  It's out, and it knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you know about spirits? You  ain't no In'dn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo knew something heavy and was  trying to tell Jimmy. But you must  not know how serious it was or you  would have delivered. Do you realize  what Leo could have told Jimmy?! Do  you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took him out before he got the  chance. He didn't say nothin' about  Tashka Sha. And now his spirit is in  the dirt. Forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's Tashka Sha, speak English,  speak English!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Red Deer Table! What's with you,  man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray grabs onto these words, rolls them silently on his li And now Yellow Bird is getting suspicious of the fed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. Wait -- what are you  doin'? You ain't a FBI. You ain't  the law. Let me see your --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray snaps out his gun, straight-armed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the fucking law!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Bird jumps back, raising his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep talking, Yellow Bird...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I know... is I did what I did...  and I ain't in solitary, gettin'  pumped up with downer, gettin' beat  to shit. But I tell you what, Suit.  Take me back. Cuz I can't take this  shit no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And then HEADLIGHTS pierce the gaps in the boarded window Yellow Bird collapses against the wall, bangs his head of it. He lets a long, pained, cry escape from under his bre and he begins a slow slide down the wall, to the floor. Ray peers out the cracks in the boards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, I don't know who the fuck I am  no more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gets up, putting his gun away and heading to the door He stops and looks back at the Indian, sitting on the flo clutching his knees, staring into the kerosene flicker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You and me both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow Bird looks at him, his glasses foggy, his face  contorted And Ray leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray steps out into the falling night. There is a car park there. With a high aerial. Ray raises a hand in a slight  wave, walks on. At the fed car, A REGIONAL AGENT behind t wheel, waves a hand. Watches Ray get into the Le Baron. Ray gets in the car and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: LE BARON
dialogues.text: Ray drives like a crazy man through the dark reservation. Through miles of open land and strange rock formations. A he looks trapped. HEADLIGHTS flicker in his rearview. He  sees this. Slams the gas pedal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron races at 85 down the dirt stretch. A moment  later a car rattles by at 90.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray reaches over to the passenger seat and pulls up the M 16. He lays it across his lap. Looks in the rearview agai Then makes a sudden sharp turn. He pulls off the road quickly, throwing up dust into the  already foggy night, the car goes out of control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The car that was following drives right past the narrow l hidden by grassy slopes and keeps flying down the long  stretch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray skids through the dirt, trying to stop -- he can't -- and the Le Baron fishtails, smashing into a chain-link fe And coming to a stop. Breathing as if he's been running not driving, Ray looks  behind him to make sure he lost the car. He did. When he  turns back to his wheel, he sees --

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE CHAINLINK FENCE
dialogues.text: lit by his headlights: THE WOUNDED KNEE gravesite. He is  right up on the arch, and the tall stone marker beyond it

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron just sits parked, headlights making the nigh fog crawl up from the base of the old tomb, along the fen The driver's door opens slowly. And Ray steps out. He wal through the arch. Into the small fenced area. Up to the s which is overgrown with stubborn weeds, half-hidden in mi Ray studies the tomb.

dialogues.speaker: AFRAID OF BEAR
dialogues.text: Weeds are grown up over the rest of the names. Ray's hand clear them, grab at them and rip them away from more name

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN HORN CLOUD
dialogues.text: With frantic abandon, Ray is ripping weeds away. He drops his knees, clearing weeds.

dialogues.speaker: THUNDER HEART
dialogues.text: MOVING DOWN and then suddenly back up to the name:

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE ON
dialogues.text: kneeling in the weeds, the wind getting restless around h screaming the way plains winds do but only these winds ar filled with a whistling. What sounds like EAGLE BONE WHIS piping shrill. Ray kneels before the marker, staring at the name on the  stone, his hair thrown around by the wind that drives acr the grass, whistling eagles, building to an unbearable, p Ray stares at the name as if he is looking through a smal hole into another world. A world that frightens him. He g up and backs away from the stone, through the gate. And g back in his car, quickly. He takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little home on the river. Dark. Empty. Ray runs up th steps, pounds at the door. No answer. Pounds again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maggie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He keeps knocking. Nothing. He hurries back down the step starts around the back of the house and something attacks him, leaps at him from the dark, knocking him off his fee into the grass. Hits him again. But as quickly as he falls, he rolls, throwing up his han and blocking a savage kick aimed for his face. He traps t boot, twists it and drops the attacker onto his back. In matter of seconds, he is on top of the man, sticking his in his throat. He grabs a flashlight from his jacket and  shines it in the man's face. Crow Horse. Breathing like a wild animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five-hundred year old turtleshell  rattle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse, listen --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's Maggie? Where'd ya take her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nowhere. I'm trying to find her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got Jimmy. Let her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse, listen. You have to come  with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? So you can get rid of me, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. So we can do what the old man  said. Red Deer Table, Walter. We  have to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse lies there, breathing heavy. Ray on top of him still clutching his gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Crow Horse are quiet as they eat up the dirt road

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe the old man's visions are still  strong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods, concentrating. After a time:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do they come in dreams, these visions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. Dreams. Sometimes durin'  sickness. Vision quest. Sweat Lodge.  Ya never know when.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just before we caught Jimmy... I had  a dream that I was being chased. And  I was running with other people. Old- fashion Indian people. I got shot in  the back. Like Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When Crow Horse doesn't respond, Ray looks over and finds him staring. He looks back to the road. And when he looks back at Crow Horse, he is still staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where was this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Wounded Knee. I mean, that's where  I was, and that's where the dream  was. Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were running with the old ones.  At The Knee. Heavy duty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it was just a dream, I --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sonuvabuck! What's with you, Man?  Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'. Forget it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse looks out the window as if to avoid Ray who is confused by the Indian's smoldering. After a moment, Crow Horse looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You had a vision. You had yourself a  vision. A man waits a long time for  a vision. Might go his whole lifetime  and never get one. And along comes  some instant Indian with a Mastercard  and brand-new shoes, has himself a  vision.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a full-blood Oglala.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've driven a long way. Where is  this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it was just a dream. Ya know,  just one of them, what do ya call  'em, fitful dreams?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Fitful dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse feels better. He looks out the window, nodding But it doesn't last long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit. You had a vision. You got  sign from the old ones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell do you want me to do?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray brakes. Crow Horse is looking past him. Ray turns. Th spectacular mesa that we have admired with every sunrise, looms massive now that we are under it. Moonlight falls o it. And the HEARTBEAT DRUM pulses from it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The land behind Red Deer Table is Badlands. Badlands pier by a few rutted old wagon roads. At a place between two  grotesque buttes, Crow Horse stops, looking uneasy. He digs into his pocket, pulls out some loose tobacco and spills it on the ground. Then he walks on. Ray observes this, starting forward, then stopping long e to fish a cigarette out from his pocket and drop it next Crow Horse's offering.

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE BADLANDS
dialogues.text: Ray and Crow Horse walk, carefully under a full moon, sca the area. Crow Horse stops, checks out some tracks. Ray w on, looking up at the table. He shines his flashlight up it illuminates -- A RED RIBBON, tied on stakes on a ridge. Ten stakes. Twen stakes. Ribbons blowing in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't prayer flags, that's for sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray sweeps the light along, walking faster, and then some frightening occurs. Something... some unseen thing snags by the leg, sucking him into the Earth with a horrible GU SOUND. Ray is drawn into a hole up to his hips, a bluish-black s oozing out around him. Crow Horse grabs him, struggling t pull him up. He does, stumbling back and stepping into a  hole himself. The two men are wheeling, throwing flashlight beams aroun slapping through a wet jelly, and finally getting their  bearings. Ray touches the ground where a blue-black chemical soluti oozes out with water from the aquifer below. His flashlig scans -- TWENTY DRILLED HOLES IN THE EARTH. A uranium strip-mining grid laid out in a 50 x 60 pattern. The far side is fence by flagged stakes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. Oil?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uranium. Test holes. Somebody came  in from the Nebraska side, and did  some shotgun testin'. They're gettin'  ready to suck this baby dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what we're doing here. National  interest. National security. Only  this time it's not gold. It's uranium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're standin' on broken treaty  ground, Ray. This ain't supposed to  be here. It'll poison the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leo knew about it. Tried to tell  Jimmy, get the Warriors involved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they took care of Leo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to the water... the river  keeps goin' down then rising again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray goes to another hole and sticks his arm in up to the  elbow, sniffs the solution.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're drainin' our water table.  That's our life, man...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is looking past Crow Horse at -- Something strange in the moonlight. COYOTES. Some forty y away, on a flat stretch of stoney ground. Six Coyotes, da in the shadows of rock formations. MOVING IN ON THEM as R walks forward, they circle... scatter... run back... circ again. Look straight at Ray, eyes glowing. And run.

dialogues.speaker: REVERSE
dialogues.text: and Crow Horse walk toward them. To the place they just l A place in the dirt, they were digging up. When they reac it, they stare down into the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: A BODY
dialogues.text: lies there, face down. Denim jacket and a shock of black  hair, thrown into tangles and dirt. It was buried. Until coyote caught wind. Crow Horse bends down, touches the  jacket... turns the body over And almost vomits when he s Maggie Eagle Bear.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: looks down in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray steps back, his boots squishing in solution and seala and soiled water. He covers his mouth, stopping himself f getting sick. And then he explodes, YELLING.

dialogues.speaker: RED DEER TABLE
dialogues.text: in the moonlight. And RAY'S YELLING ECHOING up out of the rocks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sordid little village the feds first drove through si sleepy on the rim of sunrise. A DOG BARKS hollow as the Crow Horse motorcycle chutters  down and coasts up in front of one of the little homes -- rundown but it has a satellite dish and a decent car like many. The Le Baron pulls up behind it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse walks over to Ray's window, his jeans and boot muddy. No one speaks for a long moment, the night filled crickets. And that one dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This Clear Moon's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. It's time to beat the drum.  You better wait here. He don't trust  the white man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse crosses the street. Ray sits there, and he loo almost hurt by this statement. But he is the white man. B he is Indian. He lets a long breath escape, rubs at a tem He takes out a smoke. Tries to light it. His hands are sh too badly. But he gets it lit, and sits tense, looking in his rearview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oliver Clear Moon sits in a chair, his strong Indian mout beginning to tighten at the jowls. Across from him, Crow Horse sits on the edge of a couch.  MRS. CLEAR MOON, a rotund, gentle woman brings him a coff A TEENAGE GIRL in a men's extra-large T-shirt stands in t hall, looking at him. Clear Moon in pajamas, rises, and with a coffee in hand,  starts walking in slow steps toward the kitchen. He loses control before he gets there and hurls the cup across the room into the sink, smashing it. He wheels and faces Crow Horse. He SPEAKS LAKOTA. Asking questions. Crow Horse SPE LAKOTA. Answering him. Mrs. Clear Moon, understanding, shakes her head in disbel and her eyes begin to well. Oliver, walking back to his c sits, and thinks for a moment. MORE LAKOTA. He gets up, g to a drawer and rummages. He sits again, and tosses somet onto the coffee table. It is a badge. A tribal police bad

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nervously awaits Crow Horse's words as he appears at window again. The Indian shows hope in his tired eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright. Shit's comin' down. He's  callin' council fire. All the old  chiefs and the warriors, too. I gotta  be at Grandpa's place in two hours.  We need to get the tribe together.  We need to block this thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we need... is Richard Yellow  Bird.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse looks at Ray who stares dead ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shack is just as Ray left it earlier, kerosene flicke dancing yellow through the gapped boards. Ray and Crow Ho with guns drawn, approach the front door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was a rare case of a  brother getting a break in the courts.  We did an honorin' song for him and  everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's looking at a few hundred years  in Leavenworth. He's not gonna come  out without a fight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse snakes around toward the rear of the shack. Ray knocks at the front door. It is unlatched and it crea open a little. Ray pushes it open and sees --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty wheelchair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray steps away from the door, looking around the vast pla as the sun comes up out of the Black Hills. He is roadblo and it shows in his eyes. It's all getting too big. Crow Horse leans against the shack, watching Ray. And the RADIO STATIC from inside the Le Baron. Ray pivots and sta at it as if someone is inside the car. His call signal is being paged. But he just stands there, looking at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: X21. Read. X21...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray reaches inside the car and lifts the handset. He take breath before pressing it to his lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: X21. Come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. What's your 20?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks at Crow Horse who looks equally spooked. The ag clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long, unnerving pause. No response from the other side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing on the reservation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on my way back in. Over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray holds the handset down at his side, looking over the of the car toward the Black Hills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. Ray, don't let go now, Man.  Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You go to the council fire. I'm going  back in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray swings in behind the wheel, starts the car, and barre off recklessly down the rutted road, leaving Crow Horse  behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron is already out to where sight reaches farthe than sound and silent white dust mushrooms skyward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A RAVEN is sentinel on a telephone wire that crosses the  road from the bar to motel. A few trucks remain parked in front of the joint. Ray approaches room 13, looking shell-shocked. His boots  leave blue mud prints all the way to the door. He unlocks it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray has cast off his field clothes and is halfway into on of his cleaner suits. He looks haggard but still buoyant, his eyes piercing. The connecting door creaks open and Co walks in. The SAC is freshly showered and he is fidgeting with a Windsor knot. He studies his number two man, says  nothing for a moment but is obviously holding something d His face is a red hue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (extra casual) Couldn't sleep, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray looks at Cooch. When he speaks, his voice is dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch crosses the room, and picks up Ray's jeans which lo like they went through a sandlot tackle match in a mud ho Ray tucks his clean shirt in; watching Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had to finish something with Crow  Horse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch walks up to Ray slowly and takes his face in his ha turning it toward lamp light to study the bruise along hi left eye, a residual from a Crow Horse hook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's where you were. You had to go  back and have it out with the Indian  law...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods, and Cooch slowly breaks a smile. An insecure sm but a smile just the same. He starts to laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You fucking hot head, we can get in  trouble for that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch laughs in amusement and Ray's face crinkles into a  grin as he lowers his eyes, wiping a paper towel over his face. And then, suddenly, Ray lunges at Cooch. He slams the Agent in Charge against the hollow wall, and holds him there. His eyes wild.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you tell me what we were  doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're running a cover-up and you  didn't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch suddenly explodes, throwing Ray off of him and send him reeling back against the sink. He points a finger at charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You ever put your hands on me again  and you'll be doing the books for a  baitshop in the fucking Everglades,  Mister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't tell me about Red Deer  Table --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- what the hell is Red Deer Table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? It's genocide, that's  what it is. It's a Pay Zone for some  U.S. corporation and a Dead Zone for  the people here. Uranium, Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch's eyes go frighteningly cold. He can't believe what he's hearing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ. What are you doing?  What the hell were you doing out  there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray says nothing. He just stands there, against the sink, breathing like a fighter against the turnbuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was a Selective Operations Unit,  Agent Levoi. There is classified  information pertaining to our national  security. You don't question that,  you don't go digging into that shit --  that's insubordination. Jesus Christ --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- if they mine uranium there, these  people will have no place left to  go...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were sworn in on the Constitution  to protect federal matters, Ray. I  don't know about uranium, I don't  know about Red Dog Table -- all I  know is we did our job. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We neutralized anybody with a voice.  Leo, Jimmy... Eagle Bear. Anyone who  was standing in the way of the land.  Is that it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We neutralized enemies of the  United States. Anti-American radicals  who have killed federal officers out  here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray turns to the sink, turns the faucet on to get some wa on his face. The water only trickles into the basin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, Ray. You think I don't like  the Indians? Not true. These were  noble people but their day is gone.  They're a conquered nation. They  want all of America back but they  can't even keep the garbage out of  their own front yards. It's sad,  Ray. But it's just the way it is. We  have to function as a colonial police  force out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray leans on the sink, watching the water start to spurt  free. He shuts it off. Turns to look at Cooch. And it is  then the door opens -- some knocking after the door is al opened -- and SA Miles enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gentlemen ready -- hi, Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, we're ready.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray doesn't turn from the sink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse chugs along on his motorbike toward the counci his long hair and eagle feather trailing in the wind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two federal vehicles are waiting in front of Cooch's Chev and Ray's Le Baron. One is an FBI van where Sherman helps THREE AGENTS load file boxes and computers. Cooch walks with Ray toward the Le Baron, looking at him the go. Ray looks better as he breathes the morning air. they pass the second fed car, the back window power glide down, and someone looks out with a friendly smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, there you are. The Sioux.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stops dead. Beholds the Tribal President who wears a  western cut jacket and a strained expression behind his s He hole a hand out to Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the troublemakers off our  land. Good, Was-te.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stares at him, speechless. Horrified. What is he doin here? What about the council fire? Ray somehow nods. Then walks on to the Le Baron. Cooch gets behind the wheel of car that Clear Moon sits in. Clear Moon's eyes follow Ray the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse guns past a little shack. As he does, he looks his side mirror then out across the grasslands. Then quic IN HIS MIRROR: a car has pulled out from behind the shack CROW HORSE observes this. Then twists the fuel throttle h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gets behind the wheel, looks at his watch. He is  panicking. He starts the car, reverses, slams into drive. RAYS POV: swerving and reckless as he races forward. Sh walking around to one of the cars has to run out of the w The other agents clear out, looking in confusion as Ray c a hard U -- sweeps PAST THE BAR, SMASHES INTO AND THROUGH the old hitching post -- and HEADS TOWARD the reservation which lies vast before him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With agents scrambling about, looking after the car, Cooc gets out, looking into the dust Ray left behind. HEARTBEA DRUM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RAY!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sherman appears beside Cooch aiming a questioning look. W Cooch quickly gets back behind the wheel, Sherman pulls h radio up and starts yelling into it. Cooch reaches out the window and grabs his radio arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, damn it. You call teams in and  this is gonna be a fucking media  event. Get me three cars, six agents,  block all reservation exits. It's  under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cooch squeals out with a petrified Clear Moon in the  backseat, inquiring nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse passes by an abandoned horse trailer. When he  does, another car pulls out. And follows. The first car p by. Crow Horse sees he's being followed. He cranks his thrott and the engine grinds then dies. He heels his kickstart o the fly, and keeps it alive. But his old horse is no matc for the big engines coming up fast behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray is leaving little transitional developments and trail behind. His eyes bore into the road before him, looking f a sign of Crow Horse, and in the rearview for a sign of h FBI mentor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse has the throttle open. But the two cars are co up on both sides, trying to sandwich him. To his right th Badlands loom deep, a drop into a caliche netherworld of  jagged rock. He throws the bike right, trying to ride the thin ribbon shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: THE FIRST CAR
dialogues.text: floors it, and swipes him, and the bike goes over the edg launched into --

dialogues.speaker: THE BADLANDS
dialogues.text: where it does a violent triple flip, throwing Crow Horse  then smashing into a tent shaped dune.

dialogues.speaker: A RIFLE
dialogues.text: sticks out from a window and punches the Badlands with TH SHOTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron rifles past the abandoned horse trailer. Bla smoke drifts in a wind ahead. Ray veers onto the shoulder, barely gets the car in park  before bailing and running wildly down into the Badlands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray runs, stumbles through the rock and gypsum, searching the area. He runs around the burning motorcycle, looking  left and right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse!

dialogues.speaker: CROW HORSE
dialogues.text: lies on his back in the Badlands, eyes open, fixed unmovi on the sky. Ray comes out of the flame-waves, running wit his .45 held high. He throws himself to his knees beside injured Indian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse rolls his eyes toward the FBI agent. He has a  gash behind his ear, and pink sand clings to the blood. H lifts his head, tries to form words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no Council Fire, Brother. Clear  Moon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. Come on. We gotta get off  the reservation or we're dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hoka Hey. It's a good day to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bullshit, let's get outta here,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray gets an arm under the big Indian, helps him up out of jagged crevice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grandpa...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch's car speeds down the stretch. Followed by Sherman' The FBI van. All at one-hundred and five. Gravel and dirt flies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Crow Horse half-passed out in the passenger seat, Ra keeps the wheel steady. And then his RADIO STATICS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: X21, please read. Ray. Ray. X21,  please read. This is Cooch. Please  come in, Ray. Where are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray just stares down at the radio, keeps the pedal floore The throws the wheel left.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron fish-tails in a cloud of dust and Ray leaps of the car, runs toward the little trailer, gun in hand. windows are all busted, and the door is wide open. Ray ru in. Then straight back out, shaking his head to Crow Hors Crow Horse hangs his head out the passenger window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He hasn't left this place in twenty  years. They got him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray starts to get back in then hesitates. He looks out ac the plains to see -- THREE FED CARS in the distance, fast approaching, dust ri Ray gets in quickly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch's car is parked in a roadblock. Clear Moon stands n him, and addresses UNIFORMED TRIBAL POLICE as they spill from a van, carrying rifles and shotguns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into radio) X21. Ray. Ray, please come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch has torn his tie away, his shirt is open, and he is sweat soaked. Miles gets out of a car that pulls up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have a renegade agent, Cooch? He  gets off the reservation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- he's not getting off the  reservation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And Cooch gets back in the car, drives off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Ray driving like a maniac, Crow Horse is turned arou in his seat, watching the federal cars spreading out, the chopper moving in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got us sealed. What are we gonna  do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going for The Stronghold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cooch) Ray. Can you hear me? You are fucked.  There's no way out of this. If you  won't listen to your own laws, then  listen to this: (static: a new voice) This is President Clear Moon. This  nation does not want your sympathy.  You cannot use this reservation as a  sanctuary. Stop where you are now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray and Crow Horse exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cooch) Whatever you are trying to do is  futile, Raymond. You have nothing.  Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray picks up the mic as he cranes to keep an eye on the  rearview.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yellow bird... is gonna sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Cooch) Yellow Bird committed suicide at  three o'clock this morning. Some  gung-ho agent from D.C. pushed him  into a corner. You're playing a losing  game. Pull over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray takes the mic and for some reason, he's putting it in his jacket near his shoulder where he keeps his leather.  Crow Horse looks at him, puzzled. And then the sound come forth, the static crackling of a micro-cassette recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Ray) How the hell do you know? (Yellow Bird) I blew his back out with a buffalo  gun, that's how I know. And now you're  gonna say I didn't and put me back  in solitary?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray keeps the tape running into the radio as he drives th rugged Badlands. Crow Horse, stunned by the voice, eyes R as the tape rolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch and Clear Moon stare in horror at the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (Yellow Bird) You people tol' me I could beat nine  years if I helped you. I helped you! (rewinding) I could beat nine years if I helped  you. I helped you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch is shaking his head in vitrified disbelief. He slam the pedal almost through the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tape ends and Ray now lifts the mic to his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into mic) Fuck you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he too, buries the accelerator.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron burns forward and we SWEEP UP TO A MIND-BLOW AERIAL VIEW of the Badlands as four fed cars spread out i formation, following.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse is turned around, looking at the pursuit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Walter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse turns, sees what Ray is looking at. POV: The Stronghold -- a narrow opening in hulking rock  formations. Large enough for a car to get in, and keep  followers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's it. The Stronghold. Get us in  there, we got a chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're in there. We're in there --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: just ahead, the earth is gone. A wavering heat pond turns out to be a crevice and they nose down into it, burying t front end in sand and rock. WINDSHIELD SHATTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron is stuck, wheels spinning out. Ray and Cooch bail. Guns drawn, they start running for the Stronghold.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE EDGE OF THE ARROYO
dialogues.text: the caravan slides in recklessly, two of the fed cars com dangerously close to going over the edge. The regional  officers and six Clear Moon goons empty out, running down the dip, rifles and shotguns ready. Three more field agents come down from another direction, followed by Cooch. Sherman hands a bullhorn to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (via bullhorn) FREEZE! NOW!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of FIFTEEN PRIMING FIREARMS stops Ray and Crow  Horse in their tracks. Just twenty feet from The Strongho Crow Horse, windless, stumbles to a knee. Ray turns slowl facing the small army.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DROP IT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse, rises, sucking wind, and ditches his gun in t Badlands. Ray holds onto his .45 a moment longer. Then dr it. He stares at --

dialogues.speaker: THE WALL OF MEN
dialogues.text: Cooch, SA Miles, SA Sherman, Six regional officers, six C Moon goons. And now, coming out of the backseat of Cooch' Chevy, Oliver Clear Moon, walking tentatively, cautiously Cooch lowers the bullhorn. He takes the opportunity to st at Ray. To let Ray stare at him. The older agent looks br

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse, get your face in the  dirt. Ray... come forward. Let it  go. Let's just let it go...

dialogues.speaker: AT THE STRONGHOLD ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Crow Horse lowers himself to a knee then lies face down. just stands there, the wind against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Ray. Come forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No way, Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray refuses to move.

dialogues.speaker: COOCH
dialogues.text: sweating, tries to keep control. All around him, hands ar on guns. Cooch is walking toward Ray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray. I'm coming to talk to you. I'm  gonna walk you out of here. And we're  gonna get the hell outta this place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch walks toward him, a gun hanging at one side, bullho at the other. The agents behind him, around him, all rais rifles, all take aim. Sherman, looking sick, gets to a knee and sets aim. The s of clacking steel, all around. But Cooch seems disturbed the sound. Because its coming from above. He raises an ey from the rifle sight to see --

dialogues.speaker: ALONG THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE
dialogues.text: FIFTEEN INDIANS, training rifles and shotguns down below.

dialogues.speaker: SHERMAN
dialogues.text: looks up from his rifle, bewildered. Then alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: ALONG THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE
dialogues.text: We PAN across fifteen Indians -- old people, women, kids. Their weapons are weak but many. And at the end of the row, Maisy Blue Legs rises, clutchi a rifle. And PAST HER, ANOTHER. TRADITIONAL PEOPLE, many  from the trading post porch, rise to the edge, armed. Sil Twenty, twenty-five, thirty traditionals, forming a line  along the ridge, a line that runs in a circle, broken by Stronghold entrance, then starting again on the next butt Thirty-five, forty of them. And more, standing along the  opposite craggy rock, some wearing tractor caps, some cow hats, some just long hair blowing in the wind. Fifty, six SEVENTY-FIVE RESERVATION PEOPLE forming a circle on the r it's Little Big Horn revisited. A fourteen year-old boy  struggles to keep a huge shotgun at his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BELOW
dialogues.text: Clear Moon's mouth is as dry as Badlands soil. Cooch is  panicking, his eyes running along the high edge.

dialogues.speaker: RAY
dialogues.text: stands equally astonished, assessing the back-up.

dialogues.speaker: CROW HORSE
dialogues.text: lifts himself, stands, taking in the sight.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE EDGE OF THE BUTTE
dialogues.text: stepping stiffly but steadily through the line of armed  locals, pushing his way to the very edge so as to look do Grandpa Sam Reaches. The wind makes feathery tails out of his long thinning strips of white hair.

dialogues.speaker: DOWN BELOW
dialogues.text: Ray looks up at the old man, then turns to face Cooch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Cooch. It's over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cooch slowly, lets the bullhorn fall. Then the rifle. He  looks back at Sherman who does the same, and all the way  down the line, everyone dropping their arms under the thr of a lot more guns from above. And now Ray walks forward, collecting his gun. Anderson Chasing Hawk, one of the  Warriors, runs down to Ray, breathless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the exits are blocked. There's  two more fed cars tryin' to get in.  And some press.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray notices that Cooch is staring at him, hard. He shakes his head slowly. Strongly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the press through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chasing Hawk takes off, running, and Cooch watches in  consternation. Ray just stands eye to eye with him, holdi his ground.

dialogues.speaker: UP TO ARIEL VIEW
dialogues.text: And along the ridge, Grandpa and the locals don't budge,  watching every move. CLIMBING HIGHER, we rise above the circle of proud Sioux see, on the inside of the Stronghold, thirty old trucks a res cars. CLIMBING HIGHER into and through the fast-moving clouds t the Lakota call The Grandfathers as the HEARTBEAT DRUM an LAKOTA SINGERS takes over all sound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The HIGH WINDS of THREE MEDIA HELICOPTERS are delighting storm of Indian children and BARKING DOGS, running throug the streets past junked cars on blocks. Over on a little plot of grass and dirt, a pair of hands digging a small hole. Ray lays a pine cone in the hole an looks down at it for a moment... before hand-plowing the  dirt back over it and patting it flat. He rises, knocking dirt off his knees and hands. Crow Horse walks over, bandaged and favoring wounds, and falls in with him, walking down the middle of the village road. His eyes are tired. But hopeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The people are already talkin' about  their vote for a new tribal prez.  They wanna vote for Jimmy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray nods, encouraged as they walk along. His eyes follow helicopters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bought her some time, Kola. Ain't  never gonna be over... but you bought  her some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some Indian time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They reach the dusty, dented Le Baron and stand there, lo at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Indian time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crow Horse offers a hand to Ray. He takes it in a white m shake then follows Walter's cue into the Indian "allies"  grip and slap. They hold it there, looking into each othe eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned) Where ya gonna go, Ray?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray ponders for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to see what the visions  say about that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't have another vision...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray shrugs. Crow Horse discreetly gestures below his belt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray cracks a smile, a long time coming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you ever need a place to come  back to and listen to the trees a  little... we'll be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray stands looking at him, searching for words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ain't no word in Sioux for goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ray goes to get in his car. But he sees someone sitting a the street on the trading post porch. The old man. Ray considers him for a moment then walks over. They lock eyes. Grandpa stares at Ray as if he's never seen him bef and then arcs a brow. He touches his sleeve at the wrist. Ray rolls his sleeve back to reveal his Rolex. Grandpa sm and Ray strips it off. He hands it to the old man and his face crinkles into caliche earth. Grandpa holds the watch up in the light, admires it then  puts it in his shirt pocket. He moves a flat hand through the air in the "done deal" sign language. Ray, a little  surprised that he gets nothing in the trade, returns the  smile and walks away. He gets to his car and wipes away two inches of dust from the broken windshield.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After THREE TRIES, he gets the engine started. He pulls h gun off his waistband, goes to lay it on the passenger se and finds something there. Grandpa's sacred caanunpa. The Pipe. Symbol of truth. Ray looks out the window at the old man who is watching him w those sharp black eyes. Ray lifts his hand, holds it flat and does the Sioux done deal sign.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Le Baron eats up the dirt road at a moderate, gravel  crunching pace. It slows as it passes Maggie Eagle Bear's quiet home on the river. Children walk with the old woman carrying buckets from the river. The Le Baron slows to a crawl, then drives on.

dialogues.speaker: THE TRADING POST PORCH
dialogues.text: where the elders sit, watching the dust blow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (voice lingering) We will be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CROW HORSE walking off down the road. He stops, and looks over his shoulder, trying to glimpse the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THE LE BARON driving off the res, under big sky as it asc a rough hill, waddles through potholes, negotiates with s horses in the road and rolls on toward the reservation li where the sun throws shadows that look like an old man  dancing.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE PLACE IN THE ROAD
dialogues.text: where West goes to Rapid City, and East back to Bear Cree Ray stops like the bullet-punched sign orders. He doesn't West. Doesn't go East. He sits there. Fishes a smoke out  from a pocket, clicks a lighter, and fires up. He sits th smoking. Deliberating. SUDDEN CUT TO BLACK. And after a long silent beat, A DRUM. Like a heart. END CREDITS.
